The damage ended around Bell Road north of Keim Road.  There were also isolated reports of large hail and wind damage across portions of western lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of eight to ten inches of wet, heavy snow over an approximate five-hour time period from Iron River to Amasa and Crystal Falls.  The wet, heavy snow made for treacherous travel on the 11th as many Iron County schools closed for the day.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance and wave of low pressure moving through the Central Great Lakes produced a wintry mix of moderate to heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain across much of Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Three Lakes to Herman measured four to five inches of wet snow over a five-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance and wave of low pressure moving through the Central Great Lakes produced a wintry mix of moderate to heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain across much of Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers and spotters measured a widespread five to nine inches of wet, heavy snow over a six-hour period on the morning of the 11th.  The highest totals of ten inches were reported from near Ishpeming to Negaunee.  The wet, heavy snow made for treacherous travel on the 11th as many Marquette County schools closed for the day, including Northern Michigan University.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance and wave of low pressure moving through the Central Great Lakes produced a wintry mix of moderate to heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain across much of Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced a measured wind gust of 65 mph.  Two vehicle crashes due to several trees down across Custer rd. were reported with no injuries.  A downed high voltage line cut power to most of Ludington.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were a few storms that became severe during the early morning hours of April 20th, resulting in isolated reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and moist air pushed into northern Michigan, ahead of an intensifying upper level disturbance. A few early-morning storms became severe in northwest lower Michigan.

Numerous thunderstorms developed over the area during the afternoon ahead of a surface cold front. Several of the storms became severe producing large hail, while one line segment resulted in one report of downed trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed over the area during the afternoon ahead of a surface cold front. Several of the storms became severe producing large hail, while one line segment resulted in one report of downed trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several public reports of moderate to heavy ice accumulation from freezing rain over the higher terrain around Bessemer and Wakefield. The coating of ice caused treacherous road conditions and extensive tree damage over the higher elevations of the county, mainly north of Bessemer and Wakefield.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of low pressure systems moving along a stalled out frontal boundary produced moderate to heavy freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan from the 26th into the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Officials at the Porcupine Mountains State Park reported that higher elevations of the park received over an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain which was then covered by 2-4 inches of wet snow.  The combination of the ice and snow toppled thousands of large trees which caused extensive damage to 35-50 miles of hiking trails within the park.||Light to moderate accumulations of ice and snow were reported at lower elevations which led to minor tree damage and slippery conditions on area roads and sidewalks.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of low pressure systems moving along a stalled out frontal boundary produced moderate to heavy freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan from the 26th into the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intermittent light freezing rain from the evening of the 26th through the 27th coated trees and other surfaces with a light glaze of ice.  Side roads were reported to be slippery.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of low pressure systems moving along a stalled out frontal boundary produced moderate to heavy freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan from the 26th into the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were public reports of one quarter to one half inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain over portions of northern Houghton County from the evening of the 26th through the 27th. The icing caused some tree damage over higher elevations and coated roads making travel very hazardous.  Many Houghton County area schools were closed on the 27th due to the icy roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of low pressure systems moving along a stalled out frontal boundary produced moderate to heavy freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan from the 26th into the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County Road Commission estimated between half an inch to an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain starting from the evening of the 26th and continuing |through the 27th.  The ice damaged large trees and coated roads and power lines.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 27th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pair of low pressure systems moving along a stalled out frontal boundary produced moderate to heavy freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan from the 26th into the 27th.

Lightning struck a house during the early morning hours of May 16th, causing considerable damage to the inside of house, blowing out windows, and damaging the siding. In addition the deck in the back of the house was also damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced wind damage that included roof damage to a couple of barns, a house and a mobile home.  Several trees were also blown down.  The damage occurred near the intersection of McClellan and Taft roads east northeast to the county line.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced damaging wind gusts estimated at up to 70 mph in southeast Gratiot county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pockets of damage observed roughly along a 12 mile southwest-northeast path.  Estimated 100 trees snapped or uprooted, otherwise just lots of minor tree damage. Structural damage to outhouse. A couple old barns collapsed or destroyed. Large uprooted tree landed on deck of a house. One house suffered roof damage. A garage door was caved in, leading to walls of garage buckling.  Damage to house awning.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm tracking in from Gratiot County produced a path of wind damage in Fenmore in Saginaw County associated with straight line winds with wet micro-bursts leading to pockets of enhanced damage. Another severe thunderstorm producing wind damage occurred over Sandusky in Sanilac county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a tree fell onto a car as well as power lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave in upper level flow, surface trough moving over the area during the early afternoon-evening hours. Bulk effective shear of approximately 25-30 knots. Numerous outflow boundaries help locally intensify some storms with occasional bowing segments.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees reported down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist tropical air during the day on Thursday helped to spark severe storms that began to develop during the late afternoon hours. These storms continued through the evening before the severe threat switched over to a flooding threat during the overnight hours. Heavy rain continued to fall across much of the area throughout the overnight as a cold front pushed eastward. Numerous trees and power lines were reported down south of M-59 while northwest/northern areas dealt with significant flooding. Over 6 inches of rain fell across the Tri-Cities region. June monthly rainfall total at Saginaw ended up being 10.76 inches, the most on record for June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to eight inches of rain fell, leading to widespread major flooding. 57 homes were destroyed with over 1900 homes damaged. 193 roads and bridges damaged or destroyed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist tropical air during the day on Thursday helped to spark severe storms that began to develop during the late afternoon hours. These storms continued through the evening before the severe threat switched over to a flooding threat during the overnight hours. Heavy rain continued to fall across much of the area throughout the overnight as a cold front pushed eastward. Numerous trees and power lines were reported down south of M-59 while northwest/northern areas dealt with significant flooding. Over 6 inches of rain fell across the Tri-Cities region. June monthly rainfall total at Saginaw ended up being 10.76 inches, the most on record for June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Isabella County Road Commission reported that at one point over 100 roads across portions of Isabella county in and around Mount Pleasant were closed due to flooding.  A mesonet station near Mt. Pleasant reported that 6.88 inches of rain fell from June 22nd into the early morning hours of June 23rd.  The flooding resulted in over 90 million dollars worth of property damage.  Numerous homes sustained flooding damage and the United States Department of Agriculture estimated that 21 million dollars worth of crop damage was incurred.  A state of emergency was declared for Isabella county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of torrential rainfall resulted in major flooding in portions of Isabella county, where some locations received close to seven inches of rain.  The flooding resulted in over 90 million dollars worth of damage to homes, roads and bridges in Isabella county.  At one point over 100 roads were closed due to flooding.  Over 20 million dollars worth of damage to crops was incurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding across Midland county was slow to recede, with flooding persisting through the entire day on June 23rd. Meanwhile,  near record flooding occurred on the Tittabawassee River, which peaked at 32.15 feet on June 24th at 7 PM EDT. The river fell below flood stage on June 27th at 1157 PM EDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist tropical air during the day on Thursday helped to spark severe storms that began to develop during the late afternoon hours. These storms continued through the evening before the severe threat switched over to a flooding threat during the overnight hours. Heavy rain continued to fall across much of the area throughout the overnight as a cold front pushed eastward. Numerous trees and power lines were reported down south of M-59 while northwest/northern areas dealt with significant flooding. Over 6 inches of rain fell across the Tri-Cities region. June monthly rainfall total at Saginaw ended up being 10.76 inches, the most on record for June.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding across Bay county was slow to recede, with flooding persisting through the morning hours on June 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 3.20 was measured in Gladwin; heavier rains fell in the southern portion of Gladwin County. A number of roads were flooded, and several were washed out.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving showers and thunderstorms dumped heavy rain on portions of central lower Michigan on the night of the 22nd. Southern Gladwin County was impacted by resulting high water, though flooding was much more substantial just downstate.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water continued through the day on the 23rd, with the tributaries of Wixom Lake (Edenville Dam Pond) seeing the greatest rise. Water entered a few homes located near creeks and streams in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving showers and thunderstorms dumped heavy rain on portions of central lower Michigan on the night of the 22nd. Southern Gladwin County was impacted by resulting high water, though flooding was much more substantial just downstate.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along the Saginaw River, as the river crested at 18.69 feet on June 26th at 3 AM EDT. 36 homes were damaged, with 10 roads and bridges damaged or destroyed. Near record flooding occurred along the Tittabawassee River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts brought down several trees and power lines near Muskegon.  A measured wind gust to 61 mph was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed and resulted in numerous reports of high winds and isolated reports of hail.  Numerous trees and power lines fell in a 100 mile long and 30 mile wide swath from Grand Haven to northwest of Jackson. Grand Haven was hard hit by very strong winds coming off Lake Michigan. A man was killed when a large tree fell through his house in Grand Haven. A wind gust of 91 mph was recorded on the north Grand Haven breakwater. An unverified gust of at least 88 mph and possibly as high as 103 mph was recorded by a home weather station in the South Highland area, north of Rosy Mound.  Wind gusts likely reached 60 to 80 mph across much of the rest of Ottawa county into Kent county.  A gust to 88 mph was recorded on a rooftop at Grand Valley State University in Allendale.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree fell on a home in Grand Haven and killed a 72 year old man.  An 88 mph measured wind gust was recorded at Grand Valley State University in Allendale.  Numerous trees and power lines were blown down across Ottawa county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least two individuals were swimming in Lake Superior at a beach in Alger County, east of the Laughing Whitefish River outlet, when they were both swept out towards the open waters by a rip current. Both individuals were in water that was waist deep when the first individual was pulled out by the rip current. Upon trying to rescue the individual, the second swimmer was also pulled out by the same current. The current was so strong it was reported that the individual who lost their life had been ripped out of the hands of the second individual. The second individual was able to self-rescue back to shore, but unfortunately the first individual that was pulled out by the rip current was unreachable and lost their life. Both were from Gahanna, Ohio, 612 miles away from the incident.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly flow across Lake Superior created dangerous rip currents along the beaches of Alger county, which unfortunately took the life of one individual on 8/2.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sporadic minor tree and crop damage along a path from Clothier Road between Denhoff and Brief Roads to Northeast of the intersection of Marton Road (Tuscola/Sanilac county line) and Sanilac Road (M46). Greatest observed damage was the removal of roofing material from an outbuilding near the corner of Marton and Sanilac Roads, which is consistent with winds of approximately 75 MPH (EF0). Additional minor tree damage was observed along the damage path.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado spun up from a heavy rainshower just east of Kingston in Tuscola County, as there was no lightning detected due to the low top of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes produced damaging winds, lake shore flooding and a few storms with large hail over Marquette County on the    15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of trees were down across a road in Marquette.  Time of the report was estimated from nearby observations.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes produced damaging winds, lake shore flooding and a few storms with large hail over Marquette County on the    15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter northwest of Ishpeming reported quarter-sized hail for approximately ten minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving through the Upper Great Lakes produced damaging winds, lake shore flooding and a few storms with large hail over Marquette County on the    15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hundreds of trees and power lines were downed throughout the county from the strong fall storm causing widespread power outages.  City of Marquette schools were closed on the 24th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening fall storm system tracking from the Ohio Valley to near the Mackinac Straits produced very strong and damaging north winds up to 60 mph, power outages and extensive lake shore flooding over mainly the north half of Upper Michigan on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm force north winds across eastern Lake Superior whipped up waves as high as 25 to 30 feet and caused extensive beach erosion along the Lake Superior shoreline of Alger County on the 24th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening fall storm system tracking from the Ohio Valley to near the Mackinac Straits produced very strong and damaging north winds up to 60 mph, power outages and extensive lake shore flooding over mainly the north half of Upper Michigan on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive lake shore flooding was reported along Lake Superior from Marquette to Shot Point from north storm force winds building waves as high as 25 to 30 feet.  Two people drowned when they were swept off Black Rocks at Presque Isle Park in Marquette during the storm.   A U.S. Coast Guard helicopter from Air Station Traverse City flew in for a search and rescue operation but the victims were not found in the turbulent waters.   The storm and wave action did an estimated $500,000 in damage at Picnic Rocks Park along Lakeshore Boulevard in Marquette.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening fall storm system tracking from the Ohio Valley to near the Mackinac Straits produced very strong and damaging north winds up to 60 mph, power outages and extensive lake shore flooding over mainly the north half of Upper Michigan on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting at or above 60 mph at times downed trees, power poles and power lines across much of the county on the 24th.  Au Train-Onoto and Munising public schools were closed on the 24th due the intense fall storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening fall storm system tracking from the Ohio Valley to near the Mackinac Straits produced very strong and damaging north winds up to 60 mph, power outages and extensive lake shore flooding over mainly the north half of Upper Michigan on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alger County Sheriff reported a large tree down across Highway M-94 blocking the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening fall storm system tracking from the Ohio Valley to near the Mackinac Straits produced very strong and damaging north winds up to 60 mph, power outages and extensive lake shore flooding over mainly the north half of Upper Michigan on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Painesdale to Kearsarge measured between 7 and 9 inches of wet snow over approximately 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report via social media of 14.7 inches of snow in approximately 24 hours in Erwin Township just southeast of Ironwood.   There were several reports of 8 to 10 inches of wet snow in Bessemer and Watersmeet over a 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter along the Trap Rock River reported flooding on Woodbush Road in Calumet and farther south on Cemetary Road.  The flooding resulted from two to three inches of rainfall over a 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak winds gusting near 50 mph throughout much of the afternoon and evening over western Lake Superior caused lakeshore flooding at Little Girls Point Park on the 27th.  A picture relayed via social media showed rocks and tree debris covering the parking lot at Little Girls Point.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter near Keweenaw Bay reported the largest waves he had ever observed during his 25 years at the location.  The large waves eroded the beach down to bedrock and erosion took trees down on his neighbor's property.  The boat house was in jeopardy of being lost in the water.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Paulding measured 8.1 inches of wet snow in approximately 20 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a 75-100 foot stretch of water flowing over Bootjack Road at Silver Creek.  The flooding resulted from two to three inches of rainfall over a 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The L'anse Fire Department reported damage to a park and sidewalks in downtown L'anse due to high waves and lakeshore flooding.  Highway US-2 between L'anse and Baraga was sporadically closed on the 27th to clear debris from the high waves.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong fall storm over the western Great Lakes caused flooding, lakeshore flooding and significant snowfall over west half portions of Upper Michigan from the 27th into the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report via social media of 8 inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours at Wakefield.   Five inches of snow in seven hours was also reported in the Anvil neighborhood near Bessemer on the evening of the 30th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air and deep moisture moving across Lake Superior in the wake of a low pressure trough produced significant lake enhanced snow across portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 30th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured six inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air and deep moisture moving across Lake Superior in the wake of a low pressure trough produced significant lake enhanced snow across portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 30th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 5.7 inches of lake enhanced snow over approximately nine hours.   Six inches of snow was also reported near Trowbridge Park in Marquette over the same time period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air and deep moisture moving across Lake Superior in the wake of a low pressure trough produced significant lake enhanced snow across portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 30th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow was reported with 10 inches of snow falling in a 12-hour time period in Allouez Township near Ahmeek.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow impacts western Upper Michigan bringing 8 to 12 inches of snow in some spots. Much of this snow fell during a 6 to 12 hour time period. At times visibilities down to one-quarter mile were reported with this heavy snow. SLRs were typically around 25:1 during this lake effect event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around seven inches of lake effect snow in 10-12 hours was measured over the higher terrain near Big Bay.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow impacts western Upper Michigan bringing 8 to 12 inches of snow in some spots. Much of this snow fell during a 6 to 12 hour time period. At times visibilities down to one-quarter mile were reported with this heavy snow. SLRs were typically around 25:1 during this lake effect event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Eben Junction and Chatham respectively measured 9.4 inches and 7.0 inches of lake effect snow over a 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow impacts western Upper Michigan bringing 8 to 12 inches of snow in some spots. Much of this snow fell during a 6 to 12 hour time period. At times visibilities down to one-quarter mile were reported with this heavy snow. SLRs were typically around 25:1 during this lake effect event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report via social media of four inches of snow in six hours in Laurium, and three inches of snow in six hours at South Range.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture spreading in ahead of an approaching low pressure trough resulted in moderate snow over portions of northwest Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Nisula.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shot of colder air moving across Lake Superior resulted in a period of moderate lake effect snow for the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from late on the 18th into the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours near Mass City.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shot of colder air moving across Lake Superior resulted in a period of moderate lake effect snow for the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from late on the 18th into the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Christmas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shot of colder air moving across Lake Superior resulted in a period of moderate lake effect snow for the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from late on the 18th into the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in four hours near Dollarville on the morning of the 19th.   Seven inches of snow fell in roughly 20 hours seven miles north of Newberry.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shot of colder air moving across Lake Superior resulted in a period of moderate lake effect snow for the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from late on the 18th into the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Ironwood measured six inches of lake effect snow in approximately seven hours.  West winds gusting over 35 mph at times caused considerable blowing of snow reducing visibility to one half mile or less at times.  In addition, multiple power outages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated eight inches of lake effect snow in 18 hours at Ontonagon.  The report was from the WLUC-TV6 social media page.  The MDOT RWIS site in Ontonagon measured a 59 mph wind gust on the morning of the 5th.  In addition, several power outages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 8 to 10 inches of lake effect snow in approximately 19 hours in the Houghton/Hancock area. Strong winds gusting near 55 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow with whiteout conditions at times.  Drifts of three to four feet were reported in some areas.  Observers in Painesdale and Allouez reported nine inches of lake effect snow in roughly 27 hours along with considerable blowing and drifting of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Allouez reported nine inches of lake effect snow in roughly 27 hours.   Strong winds gusting near 55 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow with whiteout conditions at times. Drifts of three to four feet were reported in some areas.  In addition, multiple power outages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of ten inches of lake effect snow in 36 hours at Keweenaw Bay.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Laurium reported one large tree down along US-41 in Calumet and two large trees down on Pewabic Street in Laurium.  Each tree was about two feet in diameter, and one of them landed on a house.  The spotter in Freda also measured wind gusts near 60 mph earlier in the afternoon with power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Painesdale measured 6.3 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.  Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph reduced visibility to one half mile at times in snow and blowing snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Newberry and seven miles south of Pine Stump Junction measured nine inches of lake effect snow in approximately 15 hours.  There was also a public report of 5 to 6 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours near McMillan. Strong gusty winds resulted in multiple power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 6 to 8 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Munising.  Local law enforcement reported hazardous snow covered roads. Strong gusty winds resulted in blowing snow and several power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 12 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Seney.   Duration of the event was estimated via radar. Strong gusty winds resulted in blowing snow and several power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of seven to nine inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours from Redridge through Painesdale to Chassell.  There was a isolated report of 13 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours near Allouez.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Keweenaw Bay.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report from social media of an estimated ten inches of lake effect snow in ten hours at Newberry.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Munising measured 11 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving across the Upper Great Lakes and a push of Arctic air behind this system generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the west to northwest snow belts of Lake Superior from the 5th into the 9th.  Strong and gusty winds also led to considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow during the morning of December 9th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow in the afternoon and evening. Total snow accumulations ranged between 5 and 10 inches, with a trained spotter in Saint Joseph receiving 7.8 inches of snow.  Whiteout conditions and intense snowfall rates were reported at times with the heavier lake effect snow bands. This disrupted traffic with numerous accidents and slide-offs reported across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper produced periods of snow and difficult travel on December 9th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across far southwest Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 6 to 8 inches of lake effect snow in 10 hours in Marquette.  Significant blowing and drifting of snow occurred resulting in one and a half foot drifts in some places and visibility was below one half mile at times. Other storm total snowfall reports from early evening on the 11th into the morning of the 12th included 12 inches at Skandia and 10-12 inches at Carlshend.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable environment along with a strongly convergent northerly wind flow setting up across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow bands downwind of Lake Superior into portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 11th into the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Newberry.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable environment along with a strongly convergent northerly wind flow setting up across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow bands downwind of Lake Superior into portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 11th into the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 12 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at Rapid River.  An estimated ten inches of snow fell in 12 hours four miles south of Trenary along the Alger County border.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable environment along with a strongly convergent northerly wind flow setting up across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow bands downwind of Lake Superior into portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 11th into the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total lake effect snowfall from the evening of the 11th into the morning of the 12th included 11 inches at Kiva and 10 inches at Traunik.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable environment along with a strongly convergent northerly wind flow setting up across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow bands downwind of Lake Superior into portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 11th into the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy lake effect snow on December 12th led to total snowfall accumulations ranging between 2 and 7 inches across the county. There was a report of 5.5 inches of snow near Paw Paw.  Intense snowfall rates and wind gusts to 35 mph also reduced visibilities leading to whiteout conditions and numerous accidents.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of locally heavy lake effect snow created difficult travel and whiteout conditions on December 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy lake effect snow on December 12th led to total snowfall accumulations ranging between 3 and 7 inches across the county. There was a report of 6.0 inches of snow near White Pigeon. Intense snowfall rates and wind gusts to 35 mph also reduced visibilities leading to whiteout conditions and numerous accidents.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of locally heavy lake effect snow created difficult travel and whiteout conditions on December 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy lake effect snow on December 12th led to total snowfall accumulations ranging between 4 and 10 inches across the county. There was a report of 9.5 inches of snow near Dowagiac. Intense snowfall rates and wind gusts to 35 mph also reduced visibilities leading to whiteout conditions and numerous accidents.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of locally heavy lake effect snow created difficult travel and whiteout conditions on December 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of five inches of snow in 14 hours at Peavy Falls Dam.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through Wisconsin dropped moderate to heavy snow into portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 13th and some lake enhanced snow into north central Upper Michigan from the 13th into the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of ten inches of snow in 13 hours near Birch Creek.  Other storm total snowfall reports included nine inches of snow in Wallace and seven inches in Stephenson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through Wisconsin dropped moderate to heavy snow into portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 13th and some lake enhanced snow into north central Upper Michigan from the 13th into the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Norway to Iron Mountain measured three and a half to four inches of snow in nine hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through Wisconsin dropped moderate to heavy snow into portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 13th and some lake enhanced snow into north central Upper Michigan from the 13th into the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service Office in Negaunee Township measured 6.8 inches of snow in 18 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through Wisconsin dropped moderate to heavy snow into portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 13th and some lake enhanced snow into north central Upper Michigan from the 13th into the 14th.

A strong clipper system tracked across southern lower Michigan. Snowfall totals ranged between 3 and 9 inches across Southeast Michigan. Travel was significantly impacted as the heaviest snow fell during the evening rush hour. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals received:||Utica          9.0 inches.|Clarkston    8.5 inches.|Birch Run    8.1 inches.|Corunna      7.5 inches. |Ann Arbor   7.1 inches. |Howell        7.1 inches.|Flint            7.0 inches.|Peck           7.0 inches.|Northville    7.0 inches.|Marine City 7.0 inches.|Lapeer        6.8 inches. |Elba            6.5 inches. |Yale            6.1 inches.|Vassar        5.0 inches.|Dundee       5.0 inches.|Bay City      4.0 inches.|Adrian         4.0 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Eben Junction measured 5.7 inches of lake effect snow in six hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through Wisconsin dropped moderate to heavy snow into portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 13th and some lake enhanced snow into north central Upper Michigan from the 13th into the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Kearsarge measured a two-day lake effect snowfall total of 14.5 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area helped generate moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 14th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two-day lake effect snowfall totals in northern Houghton County included 14.7 inches at Kearsarge, 14.1 inches at Painesdale and 11.1 inches in Hancock.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area helped generate moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 14th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ontonagon measured nearly six inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area helped generate moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 14th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Munising measured between 10 and 12 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area helped generate moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow across the northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 14th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northerly winds gusting near 45 mph whipped up 10-15 foot waves and caused beach erosion along Lake Superior at Shot Point on the 19th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northerly winds gusting near 45 mph caused 10 to 15 foot waves and beach erosion at Shot Point on the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Park rangers at the Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park estimated from four to six feet of lake effect snow fell over the higher terrain areas of the park from late on the 23rd through the early morning hours of the 27th.  At lower elevations of the park, including the park headquarters and estimated three to five feet of snow fell.  Park rangers were stuck numerous times in deeper than waist deep snow, even when traveling on snowmobiles.  The duration of the snow event was approximately 72 hours.||Periods of moderate to heavy snow were also reported at White Pine and Ontonagon from the 24th into the 27th along with bitter cold wind chills to 35 below zero on the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold Arctic air mass and periodic upper disturbances moving over the Upper Great Lakes region resulted in moderate to heavy snowfall over the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 23rd into the 27th.  Much below normal temperatures and bitter cold wind chills were also reported throughout much of the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow on December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow during the evening into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 5 and 10 inches, with a report of 9.0 inches in New Buffalo. Intense snowfall rates and gusty winds created blowing snow and near whiteout conditions at times, especially during the evening hours of December 24th into Christmas morning. Difficult travel conditions resulted with slide-offs and accidents reported across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow on December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow during the evening into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 4 and 7 inches. Intense snowfall rates and gusty winds created blowing snow and near whiteout conditions at times, especially during the evening hours of December 24th into Christmas morning. Difficult travel conditions resulted with slide-offs and accidents reported across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow created difficult travel conditions December 24th into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 5 inches. Winds picked up into early December 25th which led to blowing snow and reduced visibilities. There were reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Redridge measured 12 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours. There were public reports of 11 inches of snow in 12 hours at Houghton and an estimated 14 inches of snow in 24 hours five miles south of Hubbell. West winds gusting near 35 mph contributed to whiteout conditions and considerable drifting of snow over portions of the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold Arctic air mass and periodic upper disturbances moving over the Upper Great Lakes region resulted in moderate to heavy snowfall over the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 23rd into the 27th.  Much below normal temperatures and bitter cold wind chills were also reported throughout much of the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow created difficult travel conditions December 24th into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 5 inches. Winds picked up into early December 25th which led to blowing snow and reduced visibilities. There were reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across Lower Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow created difficult travel conditions December 24th into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 5 inches. Winds picked up into early December 25th which led to blowing snow and reduced visibilities. There were reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 24th transitioned to periods of heavy lake effect snow into early December 25th. Total snow accumulations ranged between 4 and 10 inches across Lower Michigan.

A low pressure system moved across northern portions of Ohio, bringing snow to southeast Michigan. Light to moderate snow began to work up from the southwest in the early Christmas Eve afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations by midnight ranged from around an inch across the Tri-Cities region to 7 inches over parts of Macomb County. The majority of southeast Michigan received 3 to 5 inches. Here are some of the higher snowfall totals received:|||New Baltimore            7.0 inches.|Shelby Township         6.8 inches.|Port Huron                  6.0 inches.|Farmington Hills          6.0 inches.|Bloomfield Twp            5.0 inches.|Ann Arbor                   4.5 inches.|Pinckney                     4.1 inches.|Carleton                      4.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold Arctic air mass and periodic upper disturbances moving over the Upper Great Lakes region resulted in moderate to heavy snowfall over the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 23rd into the 27th.  Much below normal temperatures and bitter cold wind chills were also reported throughout much of the period.

Much below normal temperatures and bitter cold wind chills were also reported throughout much of the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Amasa and Stambaugh recorded minimum temperatures near 30 below zero during this period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold Arctic air mass and periodic upper disturbances moving over the Upper Great Lakes region resulted in moderate to heavy snowfall over the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 23rd into the 27th.  Much below normal temperatures and bitter cold wind chills were also reported throughout much of the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around a foot of snow fell across roughly the northwestern half of Van Buren county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected the lakeshore counties of far western lower Michigan from December 28th to December 30th.  Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were reported.  Snowfall totals of near 20 inches near Muskegon were the greatest 48 hour snowfall totals since January 13-14 of 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to eighteen inches of snow fell across western Oceana county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected the lakeshore counties of far western lower Michigan from December 28th to December 30th.  Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were reported.  Snowfall totals of near 20 inches near Muskegon were the greatest 48 hour snowfall totals since January 13-14 of 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to twenty inches of snow fell across western Muskegon county.   13 inches of snow fell at the Muskegon airport from 7 pm on the 28th to 7 pm on the 29th.  Muskegon had a record snowfall of 14.7 inches on the 29th.  The measured 48 hour total of 19.9 inches from 7 am on the 28th to 7 am on the 30th was the greatest two day snowfall total in Muskegon since January 13-14 of 2012.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected the lakeshore counties of far western lower Michigan from December 28th to December 30th.  Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were reported.  Snowfall totals of near 20 inches near Muskegon were the greatest 48 hour snowfall totals since January 13-14 of 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to eighteen inches of snow fell across much of Ottawa county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected the lakeshore counties of far western lower Michigan from December 28th to December 30th.  Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were reported.  Snowfall totals of near 20 inches near Muskegon were the greatest 48 hour snowfall totals since January 13-14 of 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to eighteen inches of snow fell across portions of Allegan county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected the lakeshore counties of far western lower Michigan from December 28th to December 30th.  Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were reported.  Snowfall totals of near 20 inches near Muskegon were the greatest 48 hour snowfall totals since January 13-14 of 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reports and local law enforcement estimated two feet of lake enhanced snowfall just south of Blaney Park along the intersection of Highway US-2 and Highway M-77.  Snowfall duration was approximately 15 hours.  There was a report during the evening of the 28th of an estimated seven to eight inches of snow in four hours at the Crossroads Gas Station in Gulliver.  There were several reports of zero visibility in heavy lake enhanced snow along Highway US-2 during the evening of the 28th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air in place and the presence of an upper-level low pressure trough resulted in heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Michigan into Schoolcraft County from the afternoon of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured 14 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.  Five inches of snow fell in six hours at Deerton during the day on the 30th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of 10 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours at South Range, Painesdale and Calumet during the day on the 29th.   Additional snow fell overnight into the morning of the 30th with the Painesdale observer measuring 15 inches of snow in 24 hours and Laurium measuring 14 inches in 22 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of four inches of lake effect snow in 11 hours at Mohawk.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of lake effect snow showers dropped 1 to 3 inches of snow across parts of Gogebic County. Gusty winds resulted in blowing snow and visibility restrictions during the day.  The combination of snow and reduced visibility contributed to a snowmobile accident at the US 2 and Ramsay Crossing intersection that climbed the life of a gentleman from Wisconsin.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief period of snow dropped 1 to 3 inches of snow near the Marquette County line during the morning of December 30th.  Gusty winds produced blowing snow causing visibility restrictions less than a half mile for a time.  A serious car accident attributed to the weather conditions occurred on M-35 in Sagola Township which claimed the lives of two high school students from the Kingsford School District.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Copper Harbor observer measured 8.6 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of one to three inch per hour snowfall rates from Big Bay through Negaunee to Gwinn and Marquette to Harvey.  There was an estimated six to seven inches of lake effect snow at K.I Sawyer in around a two-hour period with whiteout conditions.  There was an estimated four inches of snow in two hours in Little Lake with whiteout conditions reported on Highway M-35 between Gwinn and Little Lake.  An estimated six inches of snow fell in five hours eight miles north-northwest of Negaunee. Whiteout conditions also caused accidents and shut down Highway US-41 for a few hours along the rock-cut between Marquette and Harvey.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds blowing across Lake Superior pushed ice into the mouth of the Chocolay River producing an ice jam.  Water backed up behind the ice jam causing flooding in the basements of eight homes along the Chocolay River near Lake Superior.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the region generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow downwind of Lake Superior in a north to northwest wind flow from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy lake effect snow band produced whiteout conditions and snowfall totals of 5 to 10 inches in far southwest Berrien County. Snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hours were experienced within this snow band. These conditions led to difficult travel conditions and numerous accidents.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band settled into far southwest Berrien County during the afternoon and early evening hours of December 31st. Whiteout conditions and amounts in excess of 6 inches were reported.

A prolonged cold spell gripped southeast Michigan January 1st to January 7th leading to the deaths of at least 4 people in the Detroit Metro Area. High temperatures were in the single numbers and teens during this stretch, with low temperatures mostly in the -15 to +5 F degree range. The cold peaked January 4-5th, when wind chills reach -25 F degrees along and north of the M-59 corridor. Flint set daily low record temperatures on January 5th and January 6th, -10 and -14 F respectively, along with record high minimums of  4 and 5 degrees on those days.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Freda measured seven inches of lake effect snow in seven hours with snowfall rates exceeding an inch per hour at times.  There was also a report of six inches of snow in the Calumet/Kearsarge area in less than four hours during the evening of the 2nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer eight miles north of Mass City measured 7.5 inches of lake effect snow in 15 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ironwood measured five inches of lake effect snow in approximately 13 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Allouez measured eight inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.  Six inches of the snow fell in four hours during the evening of the 2nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of heavy lake effect snow developed on January 3rd and persisted through the morning hours of January 6th. Three day snowfall totals generally ranged between 10 and 20 inches across the county, with a report of 17.2 inches near Buchanon. Visibilities reduced to less than a quarter of a mile at times, and snow covered roads, created difficult travel and numerous accidents across the region. There were also road closures reported in Berrien County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration lake effect snow event created difficult travel conditions January 3rd through January 6th. Three day snowfall totals ranged between 1 and 2 feet across Berrien County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Munising and Grand Marais measured between 4.5 and 5.0 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ahmeek measured five inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Allouez, Hancock and Redridge measured 24-hour lake effect snowfall totals near five inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Harvey measured five inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold Arctic air streaming across Lake Superior generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the northwest wind snow belts downwind of Lake Superior from the afternoon of the 2nd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of lake effect snow developed late January 3rd and persisted through January 6th. The heaviest snow accumulations fell across far western Cass County, where total amounts ranged between 8 and 12 inches (per radar and satellite estimates). Reduced visibilities and snow covered roads with more intense snow showers created difficult travel and accidents across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration lake effect snow event created difficult travel conditions January 3rd through January 6th. Three day snowfall totals ranged between 1 and 2 feet across Berrien County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total lake effect snow accumulations of up to 2 feet were reported from January 3rd through the 6th over far southwestern Allegan county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant lake effect snow fell across portions of Allegan and Van Buren counties from January 3rd through the 6th.  The western portions of these counties was hit hardest and total snow accumulations of 18 to 24 inches were reported in far western Van Buren county and far southwestern Allegan county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total lake effect snow accumulations of up to 2 feet were reported from January 3rd through the 6th over western Van Buren county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant lake effect snow fell across portions of Allegan and Van Buren counties from January 3rd through the 6th.  The western portions of these counties was hit hardest and total snow accumulations of 18 to 24 inches were reported in far western Van Buren county and far southwestern Allegan county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report via social media of 6.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in 8 hours at McMillan with occasionally heavy snow and whiteout conditions observed.  Five inches of snow was reported at Newberry in 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the Upper Great Lakes helped generate moderate to occasionally heavy lake enhanced snow off of Lake Michigan into Luce County on the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated six inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours at Nisula.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Allouez near the Keweenaw County line measured seven inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours with five to six inches of the snow falling within a 12-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer eight miles north of Mass City measured seven inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours with most of the snow falling within a 12-hour period.  Nearly six inches of snow fell in Ontonagon during the same time period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Allouez, Hancock, Redridge and Painesdale measured from seven to eight inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.  Most of the snow fell within a 12-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Munising measured 4.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports from Harvey to Shot Point of between five and six inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 8.6 inches of lake enhanced snow in 18 hours at Ironwood.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough extending from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes  produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 11th into the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report via social media of seven inches of lake enhanced snow in 18 hours at McMillan.  Most of the snow fell over a 12-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southerly winds ahead of clipper system approaching from the Northern Plains generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over east half portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th into the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Copper Harbor measured five inches of lake enhanced snow in approximately 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southerly winds ahead of clipper system approaching from the Northern Plains generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over east half portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th into the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Cooks measured 11 inches of lake enhanced snow in approximately 21 hours.  There was also a social media report of an estimated 16 inches of snow in 18 hours along the Delta/Schoolcraft County line just north of Highway US-2 and an estimated 12 inches of snow just north of Manistique.  South winds gusting near 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and near whiteout conditions at times across the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southerly winds ahead of clipper system approaching from the Northern Plains generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over east half portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th into the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Garden Corners, Gladstone and Rapid River measured at least 12 inches of lake enhanced snow over a 12-15 hour period. There was also a report via social media of an estimated 16 inches of snow in 18 hours along the Delta/Schoolcraft County line just north of Highway US-2. South winds gusting from 20-30 mph also caused areas of blowing and drifting snow and contributed to poor visibility.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southerly winds ahead of clipper system approaching from the Northern Plains generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over east half portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th into the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Munising to south of Wetmore measured seven to eight inches of lake enhanced snow over a 10-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southerly winds ahead of clipper system approaching from the Northern Plains generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow and blowing snow over east half portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 14th into the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observing station five miles northwest of Ishpeming measured a two-day lake effect snowfall total of 15.4 inches.  There was also an isolated report of roughly 12 inches of snow in Halfway Village on County Road 550 over the same period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Escanaba measured five inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Herman measured five inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Painesdale measured 4.6 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Bergland measured 4.8 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog was widespread across the county through the period. Local law enforcement said a 60 year old man was killed in a two vehicle crash. The man was driving west on Pleasant Road around 5 p.m. Sunday. A vehicle driven by a 27 year old male, was northbound on Summit Road, and due to foggy conditions, one of the drivers did not see a stop sign, striking the other vehicle and forcing it into a tree. The driver was pronounced dead at the scene. The other driver and a passenger were treated for minor injuries. While the fog was a factor, speed likely a larger one.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist air moved over an extensive snowpack to cause rapid melting of the snow. The result was dense advection fog which reduced visibility to less than a quarter mile and in many areas near zero. The fog at least partially contributed to an accident in St Joseph county MI where 1 person died and 2 others were injured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 12 miles west-southwest of Watersmeet measured ten inches of heavy snow in 24 hours.  Watersmeet Schools were closed on the 22nd and 23rd from the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 11 to 12 inches of heavy snow in 18 hours just north of Negaunee.  Ten inches of snow fell at the National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township and near Big Bay during the same time period.  Nine and a half inches of snow fell in 24 hours at Harvey.  Most schools were closed throughout Marquette County on the 22nd and 23rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured seven to eight inches of wet, heavy snow in Three Lakes, Herman and Watton.  Most of the snow fell over a 12-hour period.  There was also a social media report of an estimated 11 inches of snow near Pequaming in 20 hours.  Most schools in Baraga County were closed on the 23rd due to the heavy snowfall.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Painesdale and Atlantic Mine measured five inches of wet snow in 24 hours.|Houghton County Schools were closed on the 22nd due to the heavy snowfall.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Amasa to Stambaugh measured between five and six inches of wet snow in less than 12 hours.  West Iron County Schools were closed on both the 22nd and 23rd due to the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured four to five inches of wet snowfall in eight hours throughout the county.  The snow closed schools throughout the county on the 22nd and 23rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Cornell to Bark River measured between five and six inches of wet snow in approximately 12 hours.  Most schools throughout Delta County were closed on the 22nd and 23rd due to the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from the Garden Peninsula to Manistique measured five to six inches of wet heavy snowfall in nine hours.  Manistique Schools were closed on the 22nd and on a two-hour delay on the 23rd due to the heavy snowfall.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a widespread four to five inches of wet snow in eight hours across much of Alger County.  The wet snow closed schools throughout the county on the 23rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Paulding measured nearly nine inches of heavy snow in less than ten hours.  Ewen-Trout Creek Schools were closed on the 23rd and Ontonagon Schools were on a two-hour delay due the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm tracking from the Central Plains into Lower Michigan brought a wide swath of moderate to heavy snowfall across much of Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle with temperatures in the upper 20s created difficult travel conditions. A glaze of ice on roads played a part in numerous accidents across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle created slick roadways during the morning hours of January 24th. Numerous accidents were reported across the region.

A low pressure system moving across the region on Monday, January 29th, brought heavy snow to parts of Southeast Michigan. The snow began around midnight and lasted through most of the day. A very narrow swath of heavy snow occurred along the I-69 corridor from Lansing up through Flint. These areas received 7 to 11 inches. Flint Bishop Airport received 10 inches, which is a top 20 all time snowstorm. This snow made the morning commute challenging, with some lingering impacts lasting into the evening commute. Outside of the I-69 corridor, just a dusting to 2 inches fell north, while 2 to 4 inches fell along and south of the M-59 corridor.

Six to nine inches of snow fell along and south of the I-69 corridor over a 14 to 18 hour period, with four to six inches north.  Heavy snow, with 1 inch per hour rates at times impacted the Friday morning commute and persisted through the day.  This heavy snowfall resulted in numerous traffic accidents and school closures across southeast Michigan. Snow finally began to diminish by early evening.||Here are some of the higher totals received:|Saline                          8.9 inches.|Detroit Metro Airport     8.7 inches. |Northville                     8.5 inches.|Carleton                       8.0 inches.|Ann Arbor                    7.0 inches.
