EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured one-tenth of an inch of ice accumulation in six hours.  The observer in Harvey measured two-tenths of an inch of ice accumulation during the event.  A mix of snow and ice accumulation made area roads slippery.  Schools and a few businesses were closed throughout the county on the 20th.  ||A fatal two-car accident which occurred at approximately 7:55 am closed Highway M-553 in Sands Township for nearly three hours.  An 18-year-old male driver from Fennville was driving southbound on M-553 when he lost control of his vehicle and collided with a northbound minivan driven by a 41-year-old male from Gwinn.  An 18-year old male passenger from Norway in the southbound car was declared dead at the scene of the accident.  Michigan State troopers were assisted at the scene by Forsyth Township Fire/EMS, Sands Township Fire/EMS, Marquette County Rescue Unit 131, the Marquette County Sheriff's Office and UPHS EMS.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate to heavy snow moved across western Upper Michigan on the 19th, and a mix of moderate snow and freezing rain impacted central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 19th into the morning of the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred due to high water levels in many creeks, streams and rivers in the county. Several roads were closed for a period of time until flood waters receded. A few dozen structures were impacted by the flood waters as well as minor road damage. Damage of around 550,000 dollars was estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow release of a snow pack, containing one to over two inches of water, occurred in the days leading to the event which started the process of river rises in many areas. Low pressure tracked from northwest Iowa into northern Lower Michigan, which ushered in a rapid warmup and equally rapid release of any remaining water in the snowpack. Several rounds of rain occurred between the 19th and 21st of February across the region, fed by record high precipitable water levels (by February standards) in the 1.3 to 1.5 inch range. A swath of four to six inches of rain fell northwest of a Sturgis to Coldwater line. All these factors combined to cause extensive flooding in the  St Joseph river basin, with a record crest occurring at Niles. These water levels forced evacuations of homes and closure of businesses and schools, rescues from those driving into flood waters and an overwhelming of water treatment facilities in a few communities. Preliminary damage estimates across Berrien, Cass and St Joseph counties was in excess of nine million dollars.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extensive flooding occurred across the county with over 300 structures suffering varying degrees of damage from the flood waters. Several roads were closed across the area with some suffering partial washouts as rivers rose to record or near record levels. Initial damage estimates are at least 8 million dollars.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow release of a snow pack, containing one to over two inches of water, occurred in the days leading to the event which started the process of river rises in many areas. Low pressure tracked from northwest Iowa into northern Lower Michigan, which ushered in a rapid warmup and equally rapid release of any remaining water in the snowpack. Several rounds of rain occurred between the 19th and 21st of February across the region, fed by record high precipitable water levels (by February standards) in the 1.3 to 1.5 inch range. A swath of four to six inches of rain fell northwest of a Sturgis to Coldwater line. All these factors combined to cause extensive flooding in the  St Joseph river basin, with a record crest occurring at Niles. These water levels forced evacuations of homes and closure of businesses and schools, rescues from those driving into flood waters and an overwhelming of water treatment facilities in a few communities. Preliminary damage estimates across Berrien, Cass and St Joseph counties was in excess of nine million dollars.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of streets were flooded, with a couple cars stranded. Kearsley creek near Davidson reached moderate flood stage, peaking at 11.24 feet on February 21st at 800 AM EST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of disturbances traveling along a slow-moving frontal boundary to the west of Southeast Michigan brought repeated rounds of heavy rainfall to the region over a 48 hour period. As the main low pressure system moved northeastward from the Central Plains to the Upper Peninsula of Michigan on Tuesday, February 20, record high moisture content for February standards moved into Southeast Michigan. Record warmth accompanying the moisture caused the snow pack to melt as repeated rounds of rain brought two to three inches of rain with isolated amounts up to 4 inches from Monday, February 19 through Wednesday, February 21. Several rivers experienced moderate flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred due to high water levels in many creeks, streams and rivers in the county. Several roads were closed for a period of time until flood waters receded. Over 60 structures were impacted by the flood waters as well as minor road damage. Damage of around 680,000 dollars was estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow release of a snow pack, containing one to over two inches of water, occurred in the days leading to the event which started the process of river rises in many areas. Low pressure tracked from northwest Iowa into northern Lower Michigan, which ushered in a rapid warmup and equally rapid release of any remaining water in the snowpack. Several rounds of rain occurred between the 19th and 21st of February across the region, fed by record high precipitable water levels (by February standards) in the 1.3 to 1.5 inch range. A swath of four to six inches of rain fell northwest of a Sturgis to Coldwater line. All these factors combined to cause extensive flooding in the  St Joseph river basin, with a record crest occurring at Niles. These water levels forced evacuations of homes and closure of businesses and schools, rescues from those driving into flood waters and an overwhelming of water treatment facilities in a few communities. Preliminary damage estimates across Berrien, Cass and St Joseph counties was in excess of nine million dollars.

Some light freezing rain was also reported over mainly south central and eastern portions of the U.P.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of two tenths of an inch of freezing rain early on the 25th which coated trees, roads and power lines in McMillan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta County Sheriff reported a mix of rain and freezing rain across portions of Delta County early on the 28th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Briefly heavy mixed precipitation fell across portions of central Upper Michigan early on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured two inches of wet snow in two hours. Other locations across Marquette County observed freezing rain mixing in with the snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Briefly heavy mixed precipitation fell across portions of central Upper Michigan early on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured two inches of wet snow in three hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Briefly heavy mixed precipitation fell across portions of central Upper Michigan early on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of freezing rain mixing in with wet snow at McMillan early morning on the 28th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Briefly heavy mixed precipitation fell across portions of central Upper Michigan early on the 28th.

A strengthening low pressure system moved up across the Ohio valley, bringing an area of heavy, wet snow to the Detroit Metro Area. The onset of precipitation was rain before it quickly changed over to all snow by the early afternoon. Snowfall rates reached 1-2 per hour. Snowfall totals in the Detroit Metro Area reached 4 to 8 inches, with the highest snowfall totals coincided with higher elevation across Oakland and Livingston counties. The heavy wet snowfall brought down numerous branches and wires across the Detroit Metro Area leaving over 100,000 homes and businesses without power. Here are a few of the higher snowfall reports received:||White Lake (NWS)   8.4 inches. |Brighton                 8.0 inches.|Ann Arbor               7.9 inches.|Shelby Township     5.1 inches. |Romulus (DTW)      5.0 inches.

A slow-moving and occluded low pressure system in Iowa spread snow into northern Michigan on the 6th. In most places accumulations were light, but some pockets of heavier snowfall occurred. In particular, central and southern Otsego County (and small portions of neighboring counties) picked up 8 to 10 inches, with an isolated area of up to 13 inches between Waters and Lakes of the North.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of lake enhanced snow fell at Laurium in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system deepening near Green Bay produced moderate lake enhanced snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured six inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system deepening near Green Bay produced moderate lake enhanced snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake enhanced snowfall totals over western Marquette County over a 24-hour period included ten to eleven inches in Negaunee and seven inches south of Big Bay.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system deepening near Green Bay produced moderate lake enhanced snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow fell in 18 hours at Greenland.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system deepening near Green Bay produced moderate lake enhanced snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th.

A large slow moving low pressure system produced occasional bursts of snow over southeast Michigan between March 6th - March 8th. Temperatures had been above freezing the past week, which meant that ground temperatures warmed and while some snow did accumulate on the roadways Wednesday morning March 7th, most roadways (those that were well-traveled) were just wet by the late morning.  In total, around one foot of snow fell across the Thumb Region, with around 10 inches over the northern Detroit Suburbs. The heaviest snow over Northern Oakland and Northern Livingston fell Tuesday night into Wednesday morning (March 7th), with isolated totals reaching up to 8 inches. The heaviest snow fell over the northern Thumb Region Wednesday night into the early morning of March 8th,  when 6 to 9 inches fell in less than 9 hours.|Here are some of the higher 2 day totals reported:||Cass City       14.0 inches. |Kinde            11.8 inches.|White Lake     11.7 inches.|Peck              11.5 inches.

A slow-moving upper low over upper Michigan would spread snow back into northern Michigan on the 7th. The heaviest amounts fell over northeast lower Michigan, with Ossineke, Alpena, and Rogers City all picking up six to eight inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Upper Great Lakes generated moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 30th into the afternoon of the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Upper Great Lakes generated moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 30th into the afternoon of the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Upper Great Lakes generated moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 30th into the afternoon of the 31st.

A weak system brought light snow to Michigan on the 30th. A much stronger system crossed far northern lower Michigan on the 31st. This would bring a rain/snow mix to northern lower Michigan, but in eastern upper Michigan, precipitation fell mainly as snow. Six to eight inches of heavy, wet snow was common across much of Chippewa and Mackinac Counties. This was accompanied by winds of 30 to 35 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Three Lakes measured six inches of snow in eight hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Upper Great Lakes generated moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 30th into the afternoon of the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of three to four inches of lake effect snow in six hours near Hancock.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air moving across the Keweenaw in a westerly flow produced moderate lake effect snow over northern Houghton County on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall during the event included nine inches at Stephenson in 36 hours,  eight inches at Daggett in 24 hours, and six inches in 24 hours at Wallace, Menominee,  Swanson and Cedar River.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area generated moderate snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter seven miles northeast of Garden measured 8.7 inches of snow in 36 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area generated moderate snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the morning of the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters across southern Delta County measured four to five inches of snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the area generated moderate snow over portions of south central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into the morning of the 4th.

Low pressure developed in the lee of the central Rockies, and tracked across far southern lower Michigan late in the evening on the 3rd. This system produced heavy, wet snow across most of northern Michigan, with some mixed precipitation reducing snow fall amounts south and east of Houghton Lake. This late-season system produced a foot or more of snowfall in many places, including 14 inches in Atlanta, 13 inches in Levering and Tower, and 12 inches in Suttons Bay, Rogers City, Petoskey, and Kinross. Winds gusts of 35 to 45 mph occurred on the 4th, resulting in area of blowing and drifting snow. The heavy snow and winds rendered many - if not most - roads impassable early on the 4th in some areas.

This late-season system produced a foot or more of snowfall in many places, including 14 inches in Atlanta, 13 inches in Levering and Tower, and 12 inches in Suttons Bay, Rogers City, Petoskey, and Kinross. Winds gusts of 35 to 45 mph occurred on the 4th, resulting in area of blowing and drifting snow. The heavy snow and winds rendered many - if not most - roads impassable early on the 4th in some areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service office in Negaunee Township received 4.8 inches of snow in eight hours.  Trowbridge Park and Harvey measured 4.5 inches of snow in eight hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured six inches of snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Northern Plains brought moderate snow to portions of central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

An extended period of wintry precipitation struck northern Michigan in mid April. This was a drawn-out event, but the heaviest precipitation occurred on the night of the 13th into early on the 14th, and again late the night of the 14th all the way into the morning of the 16th. The initial batch was driven by an area of low pressure that crossed from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the southern Great Lakes. This produced mostly snow north of M-72 in northern lower Michigan, with an icy wintry mix to the south. Snowfall amounts of 8 to 14 inches were common, centered on the Alpena, Gaylord, Bellaire, Maple City, and Lewiston areas. The next batch, centered on the 15th, produced an ugly, sleet-heavy wintry mix. This was driven as the primary low finally moved across Indiana and Ohio. One to five inches of sleet accumulations were common across most of northern Michigan. Some light freezing rain also fell at times, but was heavier south of M-72, where ice accumulations approached a quarter of an inch. Precipitation turned back to snow before ending, and eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan picked up another 6 to 9 inches of snow beofre the system exited for go.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Menominee measured between 10 to 12 inches of wet heavy snow in 11 hours. East-northeast winds gusting near 40 mph at times also caused considerable drifting of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant moisture and lift north of the warm front generated nearly a foot of heavy snow in Menominee from late evening on the 13th into the morning of the 14th. East-northeast winds gusting near 40 mph also caused considerable drifting of snow.

A large and complex low pressure system impacted the Great Lakes region. Southeast Michigan saw heavy rain, snow, sleet and freezing rain that began on Friday (April 13) and lasted through Sunday (April 15). This system brought 2 main periods of precipitation, with a short break in between on Saturday. Total rainfall of 1 to 2 inches was common in many locations in Southeast Michigan, with 2-3 of snow and sleet north of I-69, and about 1/4 to 1/2 of ice from freezing rain between the I-94 and I-96 corridors. Widespread tree damage and power outages from an combination of the snow, sleet, and freezing rain occurred. In total, DTE and Consumers Energy reported power outages for nearly 500,000 customers due to the event. Additionally, strong and persistent northeast winds lead to lake shore flooding around Saginaw Bay and on the Lake Erie shoreline. Wind gusts at or above 50 MPH where reported in Bay county on the 14th.

Total rainfall of 1 to 2 inches was common in many locations in Southeast Michigan, with 2-3 of snow and sleet north of I-69, and about 1/4 to 1/2 of ice from freezing rain between the I-94 and I-96 corridors. Widespread tree damage and power outages from an combination of the snow, sleet, and freezing rain occurred. In total, DTE and Consumers Energy reported power outages for nearly 500,000 customers due to the event. Additionally, strong and persistent northeast winds lead to lake shore flooding around Saginaw Bay and on the Lake Erie shoreline. Wind gusts at or above 50 MPH where reported in Bay county on the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quarter to four tenths of an inch of freezing rain was reported.  The combination of freezing rain and strong winds caused power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm brought a mix of high winds, heavy rain, sleet and freezing rain.  The highest wind gusts occurred on the 14th and heavy sleet and freezing rain developed during the early morning hours of the 15th through the early to mid afternoon hours of the 15th.||Numerous accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region, including on I-94 during the early afternoon hours of the 15th. Michigan State Police requested weather conditions for an investigation into a serious head on accident on M-21 that shut the road down in both directions. Medical support from AeroMed was requested from Grand Rapids but denied due to hazardous weather conditions. Road conditions were poor in the morning into the afternoon with sleet-packed roads and ice coated roads where freezing rain was prevalent.||Total ice accumulations ranged from around a tenth of an inch to about half an inch. Total sleet accumulations reached 1 to 2 inches in some areas. Numerous flights were either delayed or cancelled.  A total of 450,000 customers were impacted by power outages across Michigan, with 110,000 Consumers Energy Customers being impacted.  Power was restored to the majority of Consumers Power customers by the evening hours of the 15th.

Power was restored to the majority of Consumers Power customers by the evening hours of the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An inch to two inches of sleet was reported.  Two inches of sleet was reported in McBride.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm brought a mix of high winds, heavy rain, sleet and freezing rain.  The highest wind gusts occurred on the 14th and heavy sleet and freezing rain developed during the early morning hours of the 15th through the early to mid afternoon hours of the 15th.||Numerous accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region, including on I-94 during the early afternoon hours of the 15th. Michigan State Police requested weather conditions for an investigation into a serious head on accident on M-21 that shut the road down in both directions. Medical support from AeroMed was requested from Grand Rapids but denied due to hazardous weather conditions. Road conditions were poor in the morning into the afternoon with sleet-packed roads and ice coated roads where freezing rain was prevalent.||Total ice accumulations ranged from around a tenth of an inch to about half an inch. Total sleet accumulations reached 1 to 2 inches in some areas. Numerous flights were either delayed or cancelled.  A total of 450,000 customers were impacted by power outages across Michigan, with 110,000 Consumers Energy Customers being impacted.  Power was restored to the majority of Consumers Power customers by the evening hours of the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quarter to a half an inch of freezing rain was reported along with heavy sleet at times.  The combination of freezing rain, heavy sleet and strong winds caused power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm brought a mix of high winds, heavy rain, sleet and freezing rain.  The highest wind gusts occurred on the 14th and heavy sleet and freezing rain developed during the early morning hours of the 15th through the early to mid afternoon hours of the 15th.||Numerous accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region, including on I-94 during the early afternoon hours of the 15th. Michigan State Police requested weather conditions for an investigation into a serious head on accident on M-21 that shut the road down in both directions. Medical support from AeroMed was requested from Grand Rapids but denied due to hazardous weather conditions. Road conditions were poor in the morning into the afternoon with sleet-packed roads and ice coated roads where freezing rain was prevalent.||Total ice accumulations ranged from around a tenth of an inch to about half an inch. Total sleet accumulations reached 1 to 2 inches in some areas. Numerous flights were either delayed or cancelled.  A total of 450,000 customers were impacted by power outages across Michigan, with 110,000 Consumers Energy Customers being impacted.  Power was restored to the majority of Consumers Power customers by the evening hours of the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of nine inches of snow in 20 hours at Ironwood and ten inches of snow in 24 hours in Watersmeet.  Northeast winds gusting to 30 mph at times also caused considerable drifting of snow.  Most schools and several businesses were closed throughout the county on the 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers north of Iron Mountain and near Spread Eagle measured between nine and eleven inches of snow in approximately 18 hours.  Northeast winds gusting near 30 mph also caused drifting of snow across area roadways.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Gaastra estimated nine inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  Northeast winds gusting over 25 mph also caused drifting of snow over area roadways.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 16th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Menominee estimated nearly a foot of snowfall in approximately 16 hours. Northeast winds gusting near 40 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow over area roadways.  Schools and many businesses were closed on the 16th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

An extended period of wintry precipitation struck northern Michigan in mid April. This was a drawn-out event, but the heaviest precipitation occurred on the night of the 13th into early on the 14th, and again late the night of the 14th all the way into the morning of the 16th. The initial batch was driven by an area of low pressure that crossed from the mid-Mississippi Valley into the southern Great Lakes. This produced mostly snow north of M-72 in northern lower Michigan, with an icy wintry mix to the south. Snowfall amounts of 8 to 14 inches were common, centered on the Alpena, Gaylord, Bellaire, Maple City, and Lewiston areas. The next batch, centered on the 15th, produced an ugly, sleet-heavy wintry mix. This was driven as the primary low finally moved across Indiana and Ohio. One to five inches of sleet accumulations were common across most of northern Michigan. Some light freezing rain also fell at times, but was heavier south of M-72, where ice accumulations approached a quarter of an inch. Precipitation turned back to snow before ending, and eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan picked up another 6 to 9 inches of snow beofre the system exited for go.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured 12.3 inches of snow in Paulding and 15.1 inches of snow in Bergland during the event.  Northeast winds gusting near 30 mph at times also caused considerable drifting of snow.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 16th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Allouez measured ten inches of snow in 24 hours. Northeast winds gusting over 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.  Schools and a few businesses were closed throughout the county on the 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The highest storm total snowfall reports during the event included 15.5 inches at Painesdale and 10 inches in Allouez.  Northeast winds gusting over 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.  Schools and a few businesses were closed throughout the county on the 16th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Homes had to be evacuated in Luna Pier. Lake shore flooding was reported in Bangor Township, with water reportedly reaching houses. Several streets reported flooding along the Monroe Shoreline, specifically in La Salle Township. Significant flooding reported over Grand Beach and North Shores, as evacuations also took place, with water impacting homes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and complex low pressure system impacted the Great Lakes region. Southeast Michigan saw heavy rain, snow, sleet and freezing rain that began on Friday (April 13) and lasted through Sunday (April 15). This system brought 2 main periods of precipitation, with a short break in between on Saturday. Total rainfall of 1 to 2 inches was common in many locations in Southeast Michigan, with 2-3 of snow and sleet north of I-69, and about 1/4 to 1/2 of ice from freezing rain between the I-94 and I-96 corridors. Widespread tree damage and power outages from an combination of the snow, sleet, and freezing rain occurred. In total, DTE and Consumers Energy reported power outages for nearly 500,000 customers due to the event. Additionally, strong and persistent northeast winds lead to lake shore flooding around Saginaw Bay and on the Lake Erie shoreline. Wind gusts at or above 50 MPH where reported in Bay county on the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations across southern Houghton County measured eight inches of snow in 12 hours during the storm.   Northeast winds gusting over 25 mph at times caused drifting of snow over area roadways.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 16th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts across the county included 12 inches at Manistique and 11 inches near Cooks.   Schools and several businesses were closed on the 16th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured storm total snowfall of 11.4 inches in Rapid River and 9 inches in Stonington.   Northeast winds gusting near 25 mph at times also caused drifting of snow over area roadways.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two day snowfall totals across selected sites in Marquette County included 31.8 inches at the Ishpeming Hoist Basin, nearly 26 inches at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township and 17-18 inches in the Marquette area.  Northeast winds gusting over 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow.  Many schools and businesses throughout the county were closed on the 16th and 17th due to the effects of the storm, including Northern Michigan University.  A 52-year-old Negaunee woman was treated at the U.P Health System in Marquette for exposure when she became stuck in a large snow bank near her garage on Midway Drive.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent winter storm moving into the Great Lakes/Ohio Valley region dumped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from late on the 14th into the 17th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported power poles were blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: East to west oriented MLCAPE axis of 1000 to 2000 J/KG existed across far southern Lower Michigan and far northern Indiana. Effective shear was maximized across northwestern Indiana but did lower somewhat with southward extent. A line of thunderstorms moved across southern Lake Michigan into northwestern Indiana. Additional storms developed further south along theta-e axis. Result was damaging wind gusts, a few that were significant with reports of trees, tree limbs and power lines down in several areas. Localized flooding occurred in some areas, mainly those prone to high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported hail of up to one and three quarters inches in diameter across portions of Newaygo county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms produced several reports of large hail of up to one and three quarters inches in diameter and isolated damaging wind gusts.

A strong low pressure system tracked through northern Lower Michigan, swinging a strong cold front through southeast Michigan early in the afternoon. Sustained winds ranging between 30 - 40 mph, with frequent gusts in the 45 to 60 mph range, with scattered thunderstorms that developed leading to enhanced winds near 70 MPH. Downed large trees, branches, telephone and power lines were reported across all counties in Southeast Michigan, with around 230,000 customers without power during the peak. In Independence Township, a large tree fell onto a car, killing the 36 year old man inside. Additionally, a postal employee in South Lyon was also seriously hurt when a tree fell on him as well. A semi was also blown over in the strong winds on US 23, blocking all southbound lanes.

A strong low pressure system tracked through northern Lower Michigan, swinging a strong cold front through southeast Michigan early in the afternoon. Sustained winds ranging between 30 - 40 mph, with frequent gusts in the 45 to 60 mph range, with scattered thunderstorms that developed leading to enhanced winds near 70 MPH. Downed large trees, branches, telephone and power lines were reported across all counties in Southeast Michigan, with around 230,000 customers without power during the peak. In Independence Township, a large tree fell onto a car, killing the 36 year old man inside. Additionally, a postal employee in South Lyon was also seriously hurt when a tree fell on him as well. A semi was also blown over in the strong winds on US 23, blocking all southbound lanes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area, interacting with MLCAPE approached 1500 J/KG and  DCAPE near 1000 J/KG. Pockets of effective shear greater than 30 knots was present. This allowed thunderstorms to develop and produce a few reports of damage across the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of rain fell across portions of Cass county, especially east of Edwardsburg in the Davis Lake area. A culvert was unable to handle the water resulting in several feet of water flowing across Oil City Road into Davis Lake. A portion of the road was washed away with trailers, small outbuildings and other items being washed away. At least two water rescues were needed, one from a vehicle driving into the flood waters and another due to rapidly rising water at a residence. No damage estimates were available.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving, compact MCV moved off of Lake Michigan during the afternoon hours of the 9th. A residual stationary boundary stretched roughly from Michigan City southeastward to Van Wert in the morning of the 9th. As the MCV moved further off Lake Michigan, the boundary lifted northward as a warm front adding to the copious amounts of moisture in the atmosphere. Flash flooding impacted portions of Cass county with evacuations, road closures and a few rescues occurring.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately two inches of rainfall in two hours from thunderstorms caused minor street flooding in Ironwood.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across a very moist and unstable air mass generated a cluster of thunderstorms which caused flooding around and north of Ironwood on the 15th.  The storm complex also generated damaging wake low winds across portions of west and central Upper Michigan.

Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Gogebic County as damage estimates from the flooding were estimated at nearly $344,000.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported in Ishpeming by an NWS employee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime-sized hail was observed in Gladstone.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Menominee County Sheriff reported a tree down across the railroad line near the intersection of U.S. Highway 41 and County Road 366 in Talbot.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed reports of fields flooded in the Vulcan area.  Also, two six-inch diameter trees were downed in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly three inches of heavy rain flooded or washed out 40 to 50 roads from Spalding Township through Daggett to Stephenson.  The Menominee County Emergency Manager reported that flooding damaged farms and toppled trees in the area as well.  There were only two homes with damage reports such as basement flooding. The Stephenson Fire Department started a pumping operation, which local farmers assisted with as well, to pump around 12,000 gallons per minute to stay ahead of the flooding. Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster for Menominee County as flood damage estimates totaled nearly $175,000.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to nearly seven inches of rainfall in the early morning hours of the 17th caused widespread and catastrophic flash flooding across much of Houghton County from Chassell through Houghton/Hancock to Dollar Bay, Hubbell and Lake Linden.  The NOAA Precipitation Frequency Atlas indicated a 1000-year recurrence interval for rainfall  amounts of the magnitude which occurred during this event. The Houghton County emergency manager reported that nearly all roads were impassable in central and southern Houghton County. Many homes and businesses were flooded throughout the area, particularly in Houghton/Hancock where one fatality occurred when a basement collapsed at a home on Canal Road.  The Administration Building at Michigan Tech University also sustained flood damage. Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster for Houghton County a day after the flooding occurred and damage estimates from flooding are currently over $100 million. Recovery efforts will be ongoing over Houghton County for the next several months.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts between two and three inches over approximately five hours caused flooding of several roads from Marquette and Harvey to Negaunee.  The Marquette County Road Commission reported the washout and closure of a portion of County Road 601 in Humboldt Township due to the heavy rains.  A NWS employee reported the closure of Lakeshore Boulevard in Marquette due to mud and debris flowing over the street.  Several other streets were reported closed in Marquette due to water over the roads.  Rescue personnel from the Chocolay Fire and Sheriff departments were evacuating residences along Green Garden Road at the Chocolay River Bridge southeast of Harvey. There was also a picture via social media of water under the bridge in Negaunee, and several residences in Negaunee reported water in the basements due to the heavy rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Possible roads washed out near Cloverland Cinemas per Public Safety Radio.  Much of Ironwood, including stores along Highway US-2, was without electricity on Sunday evening the 17th due to storms and flooding. Homeowners reported flooded basements.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable air mass in place and the presence of a nearly stationary frontal boundary produced several rounds of severe storms and flash flooding across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 16th into the 17th.  The hardest-hit area was in Houghton County where widespread rain amounts of 3 to almost 7 inches caused massive  flood damage to the City of Houghton and surrounding areas and resulted in one fatality.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous trees and power lines down in the Ironwood area via Public Safety Radio.

The month of June closed with one of the hottest days in recent memory. Highs were well into the 90s, including 99 at Alpena, and 98 at Traverse City and Gaylord. The National Weather Service office near Gaylord also hit 98; that was (by several degrees) the warmest reading recorded at that location since observations began there in the late 1990s. Heat indices exceeded 105 degrees across most of northern lower Michigan, and some locations exceed 110. The warmest reported heat index on the day was 114 near Indian River. There were estimated to be between 25 and 30 individuals who visited local hospitals due to heat-related illnesses.

A prolonged heat wave impacted southeast Michigan June 30th- July 5th. |Here are the Detroit High Temperatures for that period: 94, 93, 90, 91, 93, 96.|Heat related emergency rooms visits spiked and peaked on July 1st, and remained elevated through the rest of the heat wave.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rangers at Muskallonge Lake State Park reported tennis ball sized hail with numerous camper roofs destroyed.  All 159 campsites at the park sustained hail damage to campers, cars and other property. Seven park vehicles were significantly damaged, and the roofs of several buildings in the park, including the park headquarters building, will probably need to be replaced.  Time of the report was estimated by radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a very moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three-inch diameter hail was observed on the Lake Superior beach seven miles east of Grand Marais.  Pictures and video were received via social media.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a very moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement relayed a report of a windshield smashed by hail while driving from Muskallonge Lake State Park to Pine Stump Junction.  Size of the hail was unknown but estimated from the earlier report at the park.  Time of the report was estimated from radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a very moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The temperature at Capital city airport reached 92 degrees with a dew point of 76 degrees.  This resulted in a heat index reading of 105 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid weather occurred on June 30th in southwest lower Michigan.  High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90's which in conjunction with dew point values reaching the middle 70's resulted in heat indices that reached or exceeded 105 degrees at several locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature at Grand Rapids reached 94 degrees with a dew point of 76 degrees.  This resulted in a heat index reading of 107 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid weather occurred on June 30th in southwest lower Michigan.  High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90's which in conjunction with dew point values reaching the middle 70's resulted in heat indices that reached or exceeded 105 degrees at several locations.

High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90's which in conjunction with dew point values reaching the middle 70's resulted in heat indices that reached or exceeded 105 degrees at several locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pressure differences caused by a large thunderstorm complex moving through the area induced a seiche in Keweenaw Bay.  A significant rise in water of up to five feet in Keweenaw Bay impacted the Baraga Marina, the campground near Sand Point and many others along the bay.  Debris was washed up on US Highway 41 prompting a brief closure.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a very moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pressure differences caused by a large thunderstorm complex moving through the area induced a seiche in Marquette Bay.   Video was received at the office which showed boats  grounded for a time in Marquette Bay as seiche waters receded from the shoreline.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a very moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan during the afternoon and evening of the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette Fire Department responded to a fire on Grant Street in Marquette on the morning of the 12th.  It was determined that a lightning strike caused the fire and engulfed a small shed in flames. The structure was a total loss.  Also, the Marquette Board of Light and Power was contacted as the electrical supply for an adjacent home was damaged by the radiant heat from the fire.  Marquette Police blocked off Lincoln Street between Ridge and Jefferson streets during containment of the fire.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm destroyed a shed on Grant Street in Marquette on the morning of the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of rain in approximately six hours caused another episode of flooding in Houghton and surrounding areas within the span of month.  The Houghton County Sheriff reported several roads washed out in the Houghton/Hancock area.  This second flood episode during the recovery period of the more severe Father's Day flood event prompted Governor Rick Snyder to declare a second state of disaster for Houghton County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and isolated thunderstorms tracking across Houghton County dumped three to four inches of heavy rain causing a second episode of flooding in less than a month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash Flooding started just before midnight on July 31st and continued into August 1st.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After an abnormally dry July across lower Michigan, a low pressure system lifted up from the Ohio Valley and moved through extreme southeastern Michigan and brought some much needed rainfall. Showers on the afternoon and evening of July 31 and became heavier into the nighttime hours. As the center of the low pressure interacted with the marine layer over western Lake Erie shortly after midnight, a brief tornado formed over Wayne County despite relatively weak winds aloft. Heavy rain bands and thunderstorm activity resulted in rainfall totals near 4 inches in several locations while many more areas around the Metro Detroit area received 1-3 inches, prompting a Flash Flood Warning for the urban areas as most of the rainfall occurred over a period of 3 hours or less. A couple feet of water were reported over roadways in Dearborn Heights and Taylor during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado caused damage to a total of 3 buildings. Details include partial roof damage, displacement of a roof AC Unit, damage to a business sign, and some small tree damage. Emergency Management officials provided the details for this survey.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported two large trees were tipped over by strong winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of widespread wind damage extended from west-southwest to east of the city of Gaylord. Some of the most concentrated damage was along Van Tyle Road between Hayes Tower Road and Dickerson Road. Hundreds of trees were snapped off or uprooted. Several buildings and vehicles were damaged by falling trees. At least two homes were destroyed. One person was taken to the local hospital for minor injuries after a tree landed their home. The roof of a small business on the west side of Gaylord was partially removed. Power was knocked out to much of the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms crossed northern Michigan during the very early morning hours of the 28th. These storms produced areas of wind damage, and in some places that damage was considerable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were brought down by thunderstorm winds in Allegan county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms impacted lower Michigan during the evening hours of August 28th, 2018. Strong winds of 50 to 60 mph were common along the line with pockets of intense damaging winds of 75 to 90 mph. There were also two tornadoes embedded within the strongest winds near Baldwin and Idlewild. The most extensive damage was along US-10 from Ludington to Reed City, with separate areas of intense damage near Big Rapids and Le Roy.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One large tree was downed at Carlson Road and M-22.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A narrow corridor of damaging winds was surveyed near Wells lake.  The damage started just west of 170th ave and continued over Wells lake eastward.  Several trees were uprooted or snapped west of the lake with winds estimated near 70 mph.  More extensive damage was found on the east side of the lake where two boats were flipped and nearly every tree was snapped or uprooted. ||Eyewitness accounts of the winds lasting on the order of minutes as well as the prevalence of damage oriented northwestward suggested straight line winds rather than a tornado.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado with estimated maximum winds of 100 mph briefly touched down a couple of miles south of Au Gres, and just west of the Point Au Gres Campground. The tornado lifted near near the Lake Huron shoreline. Dozens of mature hardwood trees were snapped and uprooted. An RV at the campground was destroyed by fallen trees. One person was briefly trapped, but was not injured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down at the intersection of AB Avenue and Douglas Avenue.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across central, southern, and southwestern Lower Michigan during the late afternoon and evening of September 1st, 2018. Four tornadoes occurred.  Most of the damage was confined to trees and associated structural damage due to falling trees. Some of the storms were well-photographed and had a visible structure resembling supercell thunderstorms, including rotating rain-free updraft bases, wall clouds, and brief funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 struck near Hickory Corners.  Several trees and limbs were snapped on the northwest and northern ends of Little Long Lake in Barry county. Snapped trees also fell on a home.

Most of the damage was confined to trees and associated structural damage due to falling trees. Some of the storms were well-photographed and had a visible structure resembling supercell thunderstorms, including rotating rain-free updraft bases, wall clouds, and brief funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado occurred over rural parts of Mecosta county. A manufactured home was destroyed at the start of the damage path near Washington Road and 137th Avenue. The tornado then snapped trees along Washington Road before lifting at 125th Avenue.

Some of the storms were well-photographed and had a visible structure resembling supercell thunderstorms, including rotating rain-free updraft bases, wall clouds, and brief funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado mostly had damage indicating 65 mph winds but reached 80 mph at its strongest point halfway through its life. It began at the western Jackson City limits north of the Cascades Golf Course and continued north-northeast to cross Washington Avenue. The tornado then weakened near the railroad tracks near Hibbard Avenue.  Many trees or limbs were snapped and several trees were uprooted.

Most of the damage was confined to trees and associated structural damage due to falling trees. Some of the storms were well-photographed and had a visible structure resembling supercell thunderstorms, including rotating rain-free updraft bases, wall clouds, and brief funnel clouds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The majority of damage was concentrated in the last 1.5 miles of the path near Cutler Road to the intersection of Hollister and Round Lake Roads.  Damage to trees and structures was common along the tornado path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front entered the region, interacting with MLCAPE values above 1000 J/KG, but limited shear. PWAT's were approaching two inches in some areas causing some precipitation loading and subsequent brief downbursts or bowing segments.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were reported down around Washington Township.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought trees and power lines in Macomb county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Randville measured 3.60 inches of rain over a 24-hour period.  Most of the rain fell on the morning of the 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Peavy Falls Dam measured 4.65 inches of rain in 24 hours.  Most of the rain fell on the morning of the 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Patrons at Bear Creek Inn reported ponds overflowing onto Highway H-58 between Munising and Van Meer from heavy rainfall of three to four inches on the morning of the 5th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette City Police Department reported that sections of Division Street between Furnace Street and Joliet Road were closed due to flooding of the Orianna Brook on the south side of Marquette.  Pioneer Road near Harbor View Drive was also closed due to flooding. Runoff from three to four inches of rain on the morning of the 5th caused the brook to rise over its banks.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of rain caused the Anna River to go over its banks in Munising reaching the bottom of the bridge on Highway H-58.  Floodwaters were one to two feet deep near Brook Street and East Varnum Street with basement flooding reported along Brook Street.  The parking lot of the Family Fare Supermarket was also flooded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: By early afternoon on the 5th, the Marquette County Sheriff and Skandia/West Branch Fire Department reported that the Chocolay River had risen as high as the concrete girders on the Highway US-41 bridge just north of Yalmer Road in Skandia Township.  The runoff from four to five inches of rain which fell across the Chocolay River Basin early on the 5th caused the river to rise nearly a foot above flood stage at the gauge in Harvey by early morning on the 6th.  There were reports of basement flooding at several residences along the river in Harvey.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches from late on the 4th into the morning of the 5th caused flooding over portions of central Upper Michigan which continued into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were blown down and a few power outages were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated wind damage in the form of several downed trees and a few power outages occurred due to isolated severe storms on September 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down on Pierce Rd. between Bliss Rd. and Pingree Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated wind damage in the form of several downed trees and a few power outages occurred due to isolated severe storms on September 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a three foot diameter, half rotten, oak tree was split down the middle and was blocking the road near the intersection of M-86 and Shimmel Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through during the afternoon hours, interacting with around 1500 J/KG of MLCAPE. Lapse rates and shear profiles were less than favorable, but abundant moisture allowed for a few pockets of storms to produce some damaging winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree reported blow down partially blocking a road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought down trees in northern Oakland county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was reported blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought down trees in northern Oakland county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported several trees were blown down in Lake Diane, near Territorial Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along the periphery of an 500 mb ridge across portions of northern Indiana and southern Lower Michigan. While overall shear and moisture was limited, some drier air allowed for favorable DCAPE's in the 1000 to 1200 J/KG range. Wind damage was reported in a few locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed in Harbor Springs, and a couple of homes were damaged by fallen trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong thunderstorms crossed northern Michigan in the early morning hours. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph were common in eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan, but severe-criteria winds were only seen in a few spots.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered trees were downed in northern and western Antrim County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong thunderstorms crossed northern Michigan in the early morning hours. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph were common in eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan, but severe-criteria winds were only seen in a few spots.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large trees were blown down just south of Jamestown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe storm brought down several large trees just south of Jamestown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette County Sheriff's office reported a tree and power wires down on County Road 476 about one mile south of County Road PG.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening low pressure exiting northeast of the Great Lakes generated strong and gusty northwest winds near National Mine in Marquette County on the afternoon of the 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The path began as weak EF0 damage, mainly to trees, until near Reinhardt and Heiss roads where it became a solid EF0. The tornado reached EF1 strength near Toben and South Stony Creek roads where roofing material was removed leaving exposed trusses and windows that were blown out of homes in the area. Garage doors were also blown in and many trees were damaged and uprooted. EF0 damage to siding and tree limbs was noted before the tornado dissipated near North Stoney Creek road and the railroad|tracks.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper level trough approached the western Great Lakes on September 25, while low pressure developed over northern Lower Michigan along a cold front draped over the region. Ahead of this cold front, southwest winds brought warm and moist air (dew points exceeding 70 degrees in a few areas) to Southeast Michigan during the daytime and evening hours. This moist air mass paired with ample wind shear was sufficient to generate three tornadoes, impacting northern Monroe and southern Wayne counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF0 tornado began in Berlin Township in Monroe County just south of Sigler Road on North Dixie Highway. The tornado moved northeast about 2 miles before exiting Monroe County in South Rockwood.  The tornado continue for another 2 miles before dissipating in Wayne County. The tornado remained at EF0 strength throughout the entire path. Damage in Monroe County included multiple limbs and large trees downed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper level trough approached the western Great Lakes on September 25, while low pressure developed over northern Lower Michigan along a cold front draped over the region. Ahead of this cold front, southwest winds brought warm and moist air (dew points exceeding 70 degrees in a few areas) to Southeast Michigan during the daytime and evening hours. This moist air mass paired with ample wind shear was sufficient to generate three tornadoes, impacting northern Monroe and southern Wayne counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down.

This moist air mass paired with ample wind shear was sufficient to generate three tornadoes, impacting northern Monroe and southern Wayne counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado began in Berlin Township in Monroe County about 2 miles south of South Rockwood. The tornado entered Wayne County in Rockwood and then continued for another 2 miles, before dissipating near the intersection of Meadow Lane and Ostreich Road near the border of Brownstown Charter Township and the city of Gibraltar. The tornado remained at EF0 strength throughout the entire path length. Damage included multiple limbs and large trees downed, along with missing shingles to a house near the end of the tornado path.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper level trough approached the western Great Lakes on September 25, while low pressure developed over northern Lower Michigan along a cold front draped over the region. Ahead of this cold front, southwest winds brought warm and moist air (dew points exceeding 70 degrees in a few areas) to Southeast Michigan during the daytime and evening hours. This moist air mass paired with ample wind shear was sufficient to generate three tornadoes, impacting northern Monroe and southern Wayne counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF1 tornado began just to the west of W Jefferson Ave and south of Gibraltar Road.  The tornado remained at EF1 strength up to the Navarre Street and Young Drive area, before weakening to EF0 strength for the remainder of the path.  The tornado then crossed the Detroit River before dissipating at the north end of Elba Island in Grosse Ile Township.  Damage included multiple large limbs and trees downed, a roof partially blown off and power lines downed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust upper level trough approached the western Great Lakes on September 25, while low pressure developed over northern Lower Michigan along a cold front draped over the region. Ahead of this cold front, southwest winds brought warm and moist air (dew points exceeding 70 degrees in a few areas) to Southeast Michigan during the daytime and evening hours. This moist air mass paired with ample wind shear was sufficient to generate three tornadoes, impacting northern Monroe and southern Wayne counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports via social media of five to six inches of lake enhanced snow in approximately four hours just northwest of Hancock.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake enhanced snow bands dropped locally moderate snowfall near Hancock during the evening of the 8th.

Strengthening low pressure crossed northern Michigan on the night of the 9th into the early morning of the 10th. Snow developed ahead of the low, with the heaviest snow north of M-32, and in particular in eastern upper Michigan. Central and eastern Chippewa County, mainly near and east of I-75, picked up 8 to 12 inches of snow, with the highest amounts in Dafter, Barbeau, and De Tour Village.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 9.9 inches of snow in 24 hours.  There were also social media reports of 9-13 inches of storm total snowfall between Ishpeming and Champion.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in northern Delta County, just south of the Alger County line, estimated nearly six inches of snow in eight hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated six inches of snow in ten hours at Steuben.  There was a social media report of a two-day storm total snowfall near Cusino Lake of 15 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Alger County Sheriff's department estimated eight inches of snowfall in Munising in approximately eight hours and reported deteriorating road conditions.  There was a report via social media of 14 inches of snow in approximately 16 hours at Melstrand.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured ten inches of snow in approximately 18 hours.  There were also social media reports of 11 inches of storm total snowfall just two miles south of Baraga and 15 inches at Nestoria.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were social media reports of 15-17 inches of lake enhanced snow in the Ironwood area during the event and 15 inches near Wakefield.  Much of this snow fell during from mid-afternoon through the evening hours on the 9th with snowfall rates exceeding two inches per hour at times.  Wakefield-Marenisco and Bessemer Schools were closed on the 9th due to the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Kearsarge measured 12 inches of snowfall in approximately seven hours.  North winds gusting as high as 50 mph at times also whipped up three to four foot snow drifts during the event.  ||The inclement weather also contributed to a deadly car crash on Highway US-41 in Portage Township on the morning of the 9th.  A car traveling westbound on Denton Road failed to stop at the Highway US-41 intersection and was struck by a logging truck.  The driver of the car, a 19-year old male from Chassell, was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake enhanced snow bands developed off both Lake Superior and Lake Michigan and impacted portions of west and central Upper Mi from the 9th into the 10th.  Strong winds also caused considerable drifting of snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula.

Low pressure crossed the Lake Superior basin on the 11th. Southwest flow ahead of the low resulted in lake enhanced snow off of Lake Michigan, heaviest in parts of Emmet County. Six to ten inches of snow fell in central Emmet County during the day and evening of the 11th, heaviest in the Pleasant View area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Bergland measured 7.1 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of Baraga and Ontonagon counties from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter two miles south of Baraga measured 4.3 inches of lake effect snow in less than seven hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over portions of Baraga and Ontonagon counties from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 6 to 8 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours six miles northwest of Dollarville.  The snow report was near the intersection of County Road 407 and County Road 455 where whiteouts were observed.  Pine Stump Junction measured 5.5 inches of snow in the same period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak disturbances moving across Lake Superior helped generate moderate lake effect snow into Luce County on the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 7.9 inches of snow in 12 hours.  The snow contributed to a three-vehicle accident in Harvey.  One of the drivers in the accident was transported to UPHS for the treatment of non-life threatening injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes produced moderate snow over the higher terrain of Marquette County on the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Sundell estimated 8 to 10 inches of lake effect snow accumulation along Highway M-94 from Sundell to Rumely over a 12-hour period.  The Eben Junction spotter also reported a period of heavy snow with 5.5 inches of snow accumulation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow band of moderate to heavy snow set up over western Alger County late evening on the 20th and continued into the morning hours of the 21st. North winds gusting from 25 to 30 mph caused considerable blowing of snow as well.

Weakening low pressure tracked through the southern Great Lake Region bringing the first significant snowfall for parts of southeast Michigan. Tuscola and Saginaw counties both had reports of 7 inches or greater of snow, but amounts quickly tapered off as one headed southeast, with Monroe, Lenawee, Wayne, Macomb, and St. Clair counties all seeing less than 1 inch. Here are a couple of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Burt 7.5 |Caro 7.0|Bridgeport 6.0.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance moving across Lake Superior enhanced lake effect snow bands into Gogebic and Alger counties resulting in moderate snow accumulation on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance moving across Lake Superior enhanced lake effect snow bands into Gogebic and Alger counties resulting in moderate snow accumulation on the 27th.
