EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observing sites near Bagley and Spalding measured nearly four inches of wet snow in approximately 19 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kingsford observer and the observer three miles north of Iron Mountain measured 3 inches of wet snow during the two-day event. There was also a social media report of 8.5 inches of total snow accumulation in less than 24 hours just north of Iron Mountain. The wet snow contributed to a head-on crash on Highway M-95 near the Marquette County line which sent three people to the hospital on the evening of the 2nd.  The 21-year old Ishpeming driver of the northbound vehicle in the crash later died of his injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Bark River measured 6 inches of wet snow in approximately 14 hours while Gladstone measured 3.6 inches during the same period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated 6 inches of wet snow near Dollarville in approximately 14 hours.  The Newberry City observer measured 5.5 inches of snow over the same period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Paulding measured 3.3 inches of wet snow in 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report via social media of an estimated 7.5 inches of wet snow in 15 hours at Stambaugh and 6 inches at Iron River.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 11 miles south of Grand Marais measured five inches of wet snow in approximately 13 hours while the observer in Grand Marais measured four inches of snow. A social media report from Eben Junction also estimated five inches of snow during the event.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured a daily record 1.62 inches of water equivalent precipitation and 14.2 inches of wet snow on the 2nd.   A NWS employee two miles west of Ishpeming and public reports in Negaunee and Little Lake measured storm total snowfall of 12 inches.  Negaunee, Ishpeming and NICE Public Schools were closed on the 3rd as communities were still digging out from the storm while also dealing with freezing drizzle in the morning over the higher terrain of western Marquette County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter two miles south of Baraga measured four inches of wet snow in approximately 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of three to four inches of snow in approximately seven hours at Alston.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near the lighthouse in Menominee reported flooding of Harbor Drive and minor flooding of a parking lot at Dunn Paper Company during the evening of the 2nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting northeast from the Central Plains brought moderate to heavy  snow to much of Upper Michigan from the 1st into 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters at Freda, Chassell, Laurium measured between four and five inches of fluffy lake effect snow over an approximate ten-hour period on the evening of the 5th.  The observer near Atlantic Mine measured 11 inches of lake effect snow over a 30-hour period ending early afternoon on the 6th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance and an associated surge of very cold air across Lake Superior resulted in moderate lake effect snow over the higher terrain of western Upper Michigan and northeast Upper Michigan from the 5th into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 11 miles south of Grand Marais measured six inches of lake effect snow in approximately 16 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance and an associated surge of very cold air across Lake Superior resulted in moderate lake effect snow over the higher terrain of western Upper Michigan and northeast Upper Michigan from the 5th into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 5.5 inches of lake effect snow just south of Baraga over an eight-hour period.  The observer near Pelkie measured 4.6 inches of snow during the same period.  ||Poor visibility and slick roads from the lake effect snow contributed to a fatal head-on car crash near L'anse Bay just before 6 am on the 6th.  A 31-year-old male was pronounced dead at the scene, and a 37-year-old female sustained critical injuries from the crash.  Highway US-41 between Menge Creek Road and Plains Cutoff Road was closed several hours following the deadly crash.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance and an associated surge of very cold air across Lake Superior resulted in moderate lake effect snow over the higher terrain of western Upper Michigan and northeast Upper Michigan from the 5th into the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Ironwood reported light freezing drizzle and very slippery roads due to a thin glaze of ice on untreated streets and roadways.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly upslope wind through a shallow moist layer contributed to areas of freezing drizzle and freezing rain from the evening of the 20th into the morning of the 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette NWS in Negaunee Township measured nearly one-tenth of an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain from the evening of the 21st into the morning of the 22nd.   The WJMTV3 meteorologist also reported icy roads just west of Marquette on the evening of the 21st.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly upslope wind through a shallow moist layer contributed to areas of freezing drizzle and freezing rain from the evening of the 20th into the morning of the 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Chassell reported a thin glaze of ice from freezing drizzle with untreated surfaces remaining slippery.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northerly upslope wind through a shallow moist layer contributed to areas of freezing drizzle and freezing rain from the evening of the 20th into the morning of the 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of a two-day total snowfall of 10.4 inches at Ironwood.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from the Central Plains into the western Great Lakes brought a wintry mix of precipitation into much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 27th.  Precipitation gradually changed over to moderate lake enhanced snow for west and north central Upper Michigan on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette NWS observed a mix of snow, sleet and freezing drizzle which contributed to slippery roads and sidewalks across the area on the 27th.  The precipitation then changed over to moderate lake enhanced snow on the 28th with a calendar day accumulation of over 8 inches.  Four to five inches of snow fell in Little Lake during the evening of the 28th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from the Central Plains into the western Great Lakes brought a wintry mix of precipitation into much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 27th.  Precipitation gradually changed over to moderate lake enhanced snow for west and north central Upper Michigan on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observing sites in the Calumet area measured approximate two-day snowfall totals of 10 to 12 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from the Central Plains into the western Great Lakes brought a wintry mix of precipitation into much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 27th.  Precipitation gradually changed over to moderate lake enhanced snow for west and north central Upper Michigan on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Redridge measured six inches of snow in 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting from the Central Plains into the western Great Lakes brought a wintry mix of precipitation into much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 27th.  Precipitation gradually changed over to moderate lake enhanced snow for west and north central Upper Michigan on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Freda measured four inches of lake effect snow in approximately six hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow accumulated to four inches in six hours at Freda in Houghton County.

Low pressure tracked northeast into southern lower Michigan late on New Years Eve. Wintry precipitation surged northward into northern lower Michigan during the day. Near and north of M-72, this fell mostly as snow, and was heavy in many areas between M-72 and the Mackinac Bridge. Higher snowfall totals included 11 inches in Suttons Bay, 10 inches in Lewiston, and 9.5 inches in Kewadin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Kearsarge measured seven inches of lake enhanced snow from December 31st into the morning of January 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles northwest of Atlantic Mine measured eight inches of snow in 12 hours.  Houghton County Schools were closed on the 7th as a result of the wet, heavy snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread six to ten inches of wet, heavy snow fell across much of Marquette County.  Schools throughout Marquette County were closed on the 7th due to the wet, heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm, moist air lifting across the colder air mass in place produced moderate to heavy snow across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 6th into the 7th.  The wet, heavy snow caused most schools to close throughout the area on the 7th.

Deepening low pressure lifted across Iowa and Minnesota, passing west of Michigan. Moisture surged northward into northern Michigan on the 7th, ahead of the low. Precipitation started everywhere as snow, but in northern lower Michigan turned to sleet, freezing rain, and then rain. The heaviest wintry precipitation fell in eastern upper Michigan, almost all in the form of snow. Snowfall totals of 10 to 16 inches were common in northern and eastern Mackinac County, and all of Chippewa County. Drummond Island reached 18 inches.

Deepening low pressure lifted across Iowa and Minnesota, passing west of Michigan. Moisture surged northward into northern Michigan on the 7th, ahead of the low. Precipitation started everywhere as snow, but in northern lower Michigan turned to sleet, freezing rain, and then rain. The heaviest wintry precipitation fell in eastern upper Michigan, almost all in the form of snow. Snowfall totals of 10 to 16 inches were common in northern and eastern Mackinac County, and all of Chippewa County. Drummond Island reached 18 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter four miles south of Mass City reported 14 inches of fluffy lake effect snow and blowing snow over a 24-hour period.  The spotter also reported that the VFW and East Branch roads were drifted shut from the snow.  Schools were delayed two hours across Ontonagon County on the 19th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of seven inches of fluffy lake effect snow and blowing snow at Wakefield and Ironwood over an approximate 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Eben Junction measured six inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Eben Junction through Chatham to Forest Lake measured 8 to 9 inches of lake effect snow over a 24-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across Lake Superior generated moderate lake effect snow over western Alger County from the 9th into the morning of the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Iron River Police Department received a call about an unresponsive man found in an alleyway on the morning of the 16th.  The 75-year old man was confirmed deceased once police and EMS arrived on the scene.  Law enforcement said that health and weather were contributing factors in the man's death.  Temperatures on the morning of the 16th were determined to be around 10 above zero, but wind chills were likely at or below zero.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 75-year old man was found dead in an alleyway in Iron River on the morning of the 16th.  Police said that health and weather were contributing factors in the man's death.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station just west of Shot Point measured a peak north wind gust of 58 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds to near 60 mph were measured by a mesonet station near Shot Point in the wake of an Arctic cold front early on the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to at times heavy snow developed early on the 19th and continued through the late afternoon hours. Winds really pick up during the day, gusting between 25 and 35 mph during the afternoon. Snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 6 and 10 inches, with significant blowing and drifting reported due to the strong winds. Magician Lake received 8.0 of total snow accumulation. Slide-offs and accidents were reported across the region. A few secondary roads were impassable due to the significant drifting.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening low pressure system through the Ohio Valley produced a swath of accumulating snow and strong winds across the Lower Great Lakes region on Saturday, January 19th. Snow totals of 6 to 10 inches and wind gusts to near 40 mph created difficult travel conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.

Low pressure moved across Michigan from southwest to northeast on the 23rd. Wintry precipitation came in two waves. The first brought a few inches of snow to the area on the evening of the 22nd. Then, after a lull overnight, precipitation rates ramped up again during the day on the 23rd. Total snowfall amounts of 7 to 12 inches were common, over a fairly small portion of eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan. The highest amount, around 14 inches, fell near Royston in Montmorency County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee from near National Mine observed light freezing drizzle along County Road 581 in south Ely Township.  The WJMN-TV meteorologist observed a light glaze of ice on vehicles and windshields in Marquette.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and drizzle developed mid-afternoon on January 22nd and continued into the evening. Temperatures did warm above freezing into the morning of January 23rd while the rain continued, though sub-freezing road temperatures kept most secondary roads and sidewalks slick into January 23rd. There were numerous reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region. Many schools and businesses across the region were closed due to these icy road conditions.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing drizzle and freezing rain developed during the afternoon and early evening hours of January 22nd creating slick roads. Ice accretions of a glaze to one tenth of an inch were common.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 3-6 inches of lake effect snow fell in the 12-hour period ending on the evening of the 24th.  Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 35-45 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and occasional whiteout conditions from the 24th into the 25th.  Schools were closed on the 25th.  Wind chill values lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th through much of the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated three to six inches of lake effect snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Wind chill values lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th through the morning of the 26th.  Area schools were closed on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Painesdale and near Houghton measured between 10 and 12 inches of lake enhanced snow over a 24 hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph at times also caused blowing and drifting of snow.  Minimum wind chill values of 25 to 35 below zero were also reported from the morning of the 25th through much of the 26th.  Schools in Houghton County were closed on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer six miles north of Greenland measured eight inches of lake enhanced snow in 12-18 hours.  Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility at times.  Wind chill values also lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range by the morning of the 25th.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 6.5 inches of snowfall in 24 hours just south of Baraga for the period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Six inches of snow also fell near Pelkie. Wind chill values dropped into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th into the morning of the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of nearly eight inches of lake enhanced snow in Ironwood in ten hours.  Northwest winds gusting as high as 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility.  Wind chill values by the morning of the 25th dipped into the 30 to 35 below zero range.  Schools were closed on the 25th due to the bitter cold.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

This was one of relatively few periods of sustained heavy lake effect snow during the winter. Some of the coldest air of the winter thus far entered northern Michigan, initially on north to north-northwest winds. The lake effect snow initially focused near and west of Grand Traverse Bay during the day on the 24th. However, as winds backed late in the day, the snow pushed further inland into north central lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of around 2 inches per hour were common in the stronger bands. The highest snowfall amounts, 12 to 14 inches, fell near Mancelona and Elmira.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from two to locally five inches over an 18-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds gusting to 25 to 30 mph on the afternoon of the 24th also caused reduced visibility at times in blowing snow. ||Troopers from the MSP Negaunee post responded to a two-vehicle crash on US-41 near Brebner Road in Negaunee Township on the afternoon of the 24th.  The crash investigation determined that a 2004 Toyota Avalon driven by an 81-year cold male from Sands Township was eastbound on US-41 and while attempting a left turn drove into the path of a westbound 2006 Chevrolet Colorado pickup truck driven by a 57-year old from Champion.  A 78-year old female passenger in the Toyota Avalon was killed in the crash.  Both drivers were transported to UP Health Systems in Marquette for treatment of injuries.||In a separate incident, a Northern Michigan University student hiking and taking photographs in the Yellow Dog River near County Road 510 became disoriented in the snow and blowing snow that hit the area on the afternoon of the 24th.  Search crews looked for the male student for several days until his deceased body was located on the afternoon of the 27th just south of County Road 510. It was determined he died of exposure.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Newberry and Halfway Lake measured at least six inches of lake effect snow during the 18-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th. Wind chill values plummeted to nearly 30 below zero by the morning of the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Cusino Lake measured 14 inches of lake effect snow over a two-day period ending on the evening of the 25th.  Northwest wind gusting near 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility.  Wind chill values plummeted to 25 to 30 below zero by the morning of the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated seven inches of lake effect snow in less than six hours at Rumely.  Nine inches of snowfall was also reported ten miles south of Grand Marais in less than 24 hours. Whiteout conditions were reported for several hours on the evening of the 24th due to considerable blowing and drifting of snow along Highway M-94.  Highway M-28 was also closed from Munising to Kawbawgam Road in Marquette County due to whiteout conditions. Wind chill values dropped into the 25 to 30 below zero range by the morning of the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill values throughout the period were in the 25 to 35 below zero range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fine-flaked lake effect snow and blowing snow resulted in poor visibility across the county on the 27th.  The near whiteout conditions contributed to a multi-vehicle crash and pileup along the Seney Stretch of Highway M-28 on the early afternoon of the 27th.  A total of eight vehicles were damaged with numerous other vehicles going into the ditch to avoid collisions.  As a result, M-28 was closed for three hours between M-77 in Seney and M-94 in Shingleton.  A 67-year old man and two women, one 65-years old and the other 52-years old, received serious injuries in the crash.  All three people were transported to Helen Newberry Joy Hospital for treatment. ||Minimum wind chill values during the period were between 25 to 30 below zero.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fine-flaked lake effect snow and blowing snow resulted in poor visibility and occasional whiteout conditions across the county on the 27th.  Minimum wind chill values during the period were from 25 to 30 below zero.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fine-flaked lake effect snow and blowing snow from north winds gusting over 30 mph resulted in poor visibility and occasional whiteout conditions across much of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 27th. Minimum wind chill values during the period were between 25 and 35 below zero.

Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill values dipped into the 25 to 30 below range during the period.  Schools were closed most days between the 28th and the 31st due to the bitter cold.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Menominee measured six inches of snow in 12 hours with visibility about one block during the storm event.  Northeast winds gusting to around 30 mph caused most area roads to become drifted shut and nearly impassible with most businesses closed.

Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill values through much of the period were in the 25 to 30 below zero range.  Area schools were closed for most days from the 28th into the 31st due to the bitter cold.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to eleven inches was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system reached Lower Michigan on January 28th.  Blizzard conditions were common from North Dakota to southern Wisconsin, with snow falling heavily in Lower Michigan on the 28th. Snowfall totals were generally from 4 to 10 inches, with a stripe of higher amounts along and north of Highway 10.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eleven inches was reported.

Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread around daybreak on January 28th and continued through early January 29th. Some freezing drizzle did mix in during the late afternoon and evening hours. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 7 and 10 inches. A trained spotter 1 mile southwest of Fair Plain received 9.0 inches of snow. Gusty winds to near 30 mph led to considerable blowing and drifting snow which resulted in limited visibility and difficult travel. There were numerous school delays and cancellations, along with reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Alberta Clipper brought heavy snow and gusty winds to Lower Michigan January 28th into early January 29th. Snow accumulations generally ranged between 4 and 9 inches.

Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

Strong low pressure tracked through southeast Michigan, leading to a wide range in snowfall amounts, with the least amounts south of I-94, and the highest amounts occurring north of I-69. Snowfall amounts ranged from around 2 inches in Monroe to 10 inches over Bay and Huron counties. In addition, strong northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph coming of Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay lead to some blowing and drifting of the snow north of I-69 as well.  Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received:||Harbor Beach... 10 inches.|Bay City (4N)... 10 inches.|Bad Axe...   9 inches.|Cass City... 8 inches. |Lapeer...    8 inches. |Columbiaville... 8 inches.|Marlette... 7 inches.|Leonard... 6 inches.|Manchester... 5 inches.|Detroit Metro... 4 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of lake effect snow fell.  This in conjunction with bitterly cold air and gusty winds that resulted in dangerously cold wind chills as cold as 20 to 40 below zero at times.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass moved over the Midwest, lake effect snow increased over the eastern Lake Michigan shore and continued almost nonstop from January 29th to 31st. Normally a prolonged period of lake effect snow would lead to impressive snow totals, but the extremely cold air mass did not allow for efficient snowflake production.  Nonetheless, the small snowflakes combined with gusty winds lead to a prolonged period of low visibility to near-blizzard conditions, especially along and west of US-131.||The lake effect snow finally ended Thursday evening, leaving behind an additional 6 to 12 inches of snow.   The combination of falling snow, gusty winds, and light snow led to considerable blowing snow restricting visibilities across Lower Michigan for a prolonged period of time.  In many areas, visibility was at or below 3 miles for days in a row, with extended periods of at or below 1/4 of a mile.  There were hundreds of school closings during this period.

Another blast of arctic air impacted northern Michigan, behind a departing area of low pressure. Lake effect snow, gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow, and very low wind chills, combined to produce an abundance of winter weather hazards in northern Michigan. Wind chills bottomed out at 25 to 35 below zero in most of northern Michigan. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were reported from Good Hart, Brethren, Boyne City, and Indian River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer six miles north of Greenland measured nearly eight inches of lake enhanced snow in 12 to 24 hours.  Northwest winds gusting to around 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and near whiteout conditions at times.  Minimum wind chills were 25 to 30 below through the period. Most schools throughout the county were closed from the 29th into the 31st due the extreme winter weather.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to eight inches of lake effect snow were observed throughout the county in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 30th.  Northwest winds gusting near 35 mph caused near-blizzard conditions at times in snow and blowing snow.  Area schools were closed from the 29th into the 31st due to the extreme winter weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated two to four inches of lake effect snow occurred every 12-24 hours through the period.  Northwest winds gusting to 40 mph caused near-blizzard conditions at times in snow and blowing snow.  Schools were closed throughout the county from the 29th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake snowfall totals reached as high as 12-14 inches at Wetmore and Au Train for the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 30th.  Northwest winds frequently gusting to 35 mph or greater caused blizzard conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow throughout much of period.  Highway M-28 was closed by law enforcement from Munising to the Marquette County line on the afternoon of the 29th and remain closed into the morning of the 31st.  Schools were closed throughout the period.

On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occasional whiteouts in heavy snow and blowing snow were reported by county law enforcement throughout the afternoon of the 29th into the morning of the 31st.  M-28 was closed due to the extreme blowing and drifting of snow over the road from northwest winds gusting to 35 mph.  Area schools remained closed throughout the period.

An arctic air outbreak into the Midwest at the end of January 2019 brought extreme low temperatures and dangerous wind chills for several days. Numerous low temperature records were set across the area. The arctic front moved through Southeast Michigan on Tuesday, January 29 and temperatures fell to below zero by early Wednesday morning. In fact, the high temperatures for Wednesday in Detroit and Flint were recorded at midnight as temps remained below zero all day into Thursday. Detroit spent 36 consecutive hours below 0 - this was the longest such streak since Jan. 1994 (66 hours). Flint also spent 36 hours below 0. A tightened pressure gradient over the region and excellent mixing led to winds gusting over 35 mph at times from Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. The result was wind chills near or below -35 for numerous hours. Two deaths were attributed to the cold in Wayne County.

An arctic air outbreak into the Midwest at the end of January 2019 brought extreme low temperatures and dangerous wind chills for several days. Numerous low temperature records were set across the area. The arctic front moved through Southeast Michigan on Tuesday, January 29 and temperatures fell to below zero by early Wednesday morning. In fact, the high temperatures for Wednesday in Detroit and Flint were recorded at midnight as temps remained below zero all day into Thursday. Detroit spent 36 consecutive hours below 0 - this was the longest such streak since Jan. 1994 (66 hours). Flint also spent 36 hours below 0. A tightened pressure gradient over the region and excellent mixing led to winds gusting over 35 mph at times from Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. The result was wind chills near or below -35 for numerous hours. Two deaths were attributed to the cold in Wayne County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty west winds ushered in a bitterly cold arctic air mass on January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. The coldest of the air and strongest winds occurred during the morning hours of January 30th when the wind chill value at Coldwater dropped to 40 degrees below zero. Wind chills through the event generally ranged between 25 and 40 degrees below zero. The coldest air temperature recorded at Batavia was 19 degrees below zero on January 30th. Many businesses and schools were closed on both January 30th and January 31st due to this record breaking shot of dangerous cold air.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous arctic air mass overspread Lower Michigan January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. Wind chills between 25 and 40 degrees below zero were common.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty west winds ushered in a bitterly cold arctic air mass on January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. The coldest of the air and strongest winds occurred during the morning hours of January 30th when the wind chill value at Three Rivers dropped to 39 degrees below zero. Wind chills through the event generally ranged between 25 and 40 degrees below zero. The coldest air temperature recorded at Three Rivers was 19 degrees below zero on January 31st. Many businesses and schools were closed on both January 30th and January 31st due to this record breaking shot of dangerous cold air. Lake effect snow showers and blowing snow also helped wreak havoc on area roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous arctic air mass overspread Lower Michigan January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. Wind chills between 25 and 40 degrees below zero were common.

Another blast of arctic air impacted northern Michigan, behind a departing area of low pressure. Lake effect snow, gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow, and very low wind chills, combined to produce an abundance of winter weather hazards in northern Michigan. Wind chills bottomed out at 25 to 35 below zero in most of northern Michigan. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were reported from Good Hart, Brethren, Boyne City, and Indian River.

Low pressure crossed the northern Great Lakes on the afternoon of the 4th. A lengthy period of freezing drizzle gave way to a more substantial wintry mix as the low approached. This fell as mostly freezing rain in Chippewa County. Around three-tenths of an inch of ice accumulation was measured in Sault Ste Marie.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Ironwood and Watersmeet reported a quarter of an inch of ice accumulation. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 4th due to the ice and slippery conditions.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through the Upper Great Lakes dropped significant ice accumulation across much of Upper Michigan on the 4th.  As a result, schools were closed throughout Upper Michigan on the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated one tenth to one quarter inch of ice accumulation occurred across Menominee County on the morning of the 4th. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 4th due to the ice and slippery conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One quarter to one half inch of ice accumulation occurred across Dickinson County on the morning of the 4th. The ice caused tree damage and power outages across the county which impacted hundreds of Wisconsin Electric customers from Iron Mountain to Ralph. An upper level disturbance spread snow across the northern Great Lakes on the afternoon and night of the 5th. This snow was mostly light, however some bands of heavier snow focused on Mackinac County in eastern upper Michigan. Allenville and St Ignace picked up 6 to 7 inches of snow in a short time period, as accumulation rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Parent Bay measured six inches of snow in 12 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes brought heavy snow to much of south central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 5th into the early morning of the 6th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain resulted in numerous downed trees, limbs, power lines and widespread power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two periods of freezing rain from February 5th through February 7th resulted in significant ice accumulation on the order of a half to three quarters of an inch across portions of central lower Michigan.  This resulted in thousands of downed trees, limbs and power lines.  Approximately one hundred and fifty thousand people lost power.  |Schools in the area were closed for days.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam formed and held in Portland for three weeks, resulting in significant flooding and around 200,000 dollars in damage to public facilities.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6, 2019 an ice jam formed on the Grand River in Portland. Approximately 50 residents were evacuated from their homes along Water Street in downtown Portland. 2 days later, on February 8, the ice jam shifted and thickened, causing additional flooding. Many businesses along Kent Street were flooded, and residents along Canal and Market streets were evacuated. The ice jam held for more than 3 weeks before finally melting and shifting downstream. Some homes on Water Street experienced continuous flooding for most of this 3 week period. The flooding caused approximately $200,000 damage to public facilities alone. This total does not include the damage to private homes and businesses from the flood.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of six inches of snow in 12 hours at Ironwood.  There was a five hour period of one-inch per hour snowfall rates from late morning to mid afternoon on the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a media report of eight inches of snow in 12 hours at Copper Harbor.  Four inches of snow fell in less than three hours during the afternoon of the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Painesdale measured 14.5 inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 8th.  12-hour snow amounts included eight to nine inches at Chassell and Hancock. Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure would pass to our west and north, eventually reaching James Bay. Warmer air surged into the region aloft ahead of the system, resulting in another wintry mix in the region. Parts of northern lower Michigan saw freezing rain of around a quarter of an inch during the day on the 7th, including Gaylord, Grayling, Higgins Lake, Charlevoix, and Alpena. Cold air rushed back in behind the departing system, and locally heavy lake effect snow developed, especially from Leelanau County to Otsego County. A quick 6 to 8 inches of snow fell on parts of the Gaylord area during the early morning hours of the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six to eight inches of snow fell in approximately seven hours.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Amasa measured five inches of snow in six hours on the afternoon of the 7th.  Schools were closed or delayed two hours on the 8th due to effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Norway measured six inches of snow in approximately nine hours. Bay College in Iron Mountain was dismissed early on the 7th due to the storm and many schools delayed classes two hours on the 8th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media reports observed ten inches of snow in seven hours at Bergland and Mass City.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed on the 8th due to the storm.

Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotters throughout the county measured three to four inches of snow in approximately six hours during the afternoon of the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 8th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 3.6 inches of snow in Escanaba in less than ten hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated eight to ten inched of snow in Baraga in less than seven hours. Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and were delayed two hours on the 8th due to the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread seven to eight inches of snow fell across the northern half of the county in eight hours during the afternoon of the 7th. The heavy snow and poor visibility led to a two-vehicle crash near the Lakeshore Drive intersection in Ishpeming during the afternoon of the 7th which resulted three injured people.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed on the 8th due to the storm. Highway M-28 was closed east of Harvey due to blizzard conditions by the evening of the 7th.  Strong northwest winds gusting near 45 mph on the morning of the 8th toppled a 8-10 inch diameter tree across North Road in Negaunee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media report estimated eight to nine inches of snow in approximately seven hours at Deerton and Munising.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to five inches of snow fell in approximately seven hours during the afternoon of the 7th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed by webcams along Highway M-28 during the period. Northwest winds were likely gusting to 35 mph at times and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th. Schools were dismissed early on the 7th and remained closed through the 8th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported by the observer in Grand Marais and observed at times on webcams along Highway M-28 during the period. Northwest winds were frequently gusting to 35 mph, especially near the shore of Lake Superior and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported by the observer in Grand Marais and observed on webcams along Highway M-28 during the period.  Northwest winds were frequently gusting to 35 mph at the Munising ASOS and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th. Schools were dismissed early on the 7th and remained closed through the 8th due to the effects of the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated six to seven inches of snow in 11 hours near Menominee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving across the Upper Great Lakes produced moderate snow over Menominee on the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain, at times mixed with sleet, accumulated up to 0.30 inches in spots on February 12th. Numerous slide-offs and minor accidents occurred across the county. Many schools and some businesses were closed on February 12th due to the icy conditions. Fallen tree branches were reported across the region, with many onto power lines creating scattered power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated to near a quarter of an inch during the morning of February 12th as low pressure lifted north toward the Lower Great Lakes region. This created difficult travel, along with scattered power outages due to falling trees and tree limbs.

A strong low pressure system brought a wintry mix to southeast Michigan on February 12th.  Snow started to work in across the area from the Ohio border around midnight and continued to move north into the morning hours. Warmer air aloft also moved in from south to north and led to the development of a mix of precipitation across the region. Easterly winds gusting to around 25 mph during the morning fed plenty of cold Canadian air to the surface, allowing for freezing rain to dominate south of Detroit where tens of thousands of residents lost power. Ice accumulation up to 3 tenths of an inch was observed over Monroe and Lenawee counties.  Sleet was more prevalent to the north. Eventually temperatures rose above freezing by the late morning, leading to a changeover to liquid rain. Precipitation tapered off across the region by early afternoon as the system's dry slot moved in. Snowfall amounts north of M-59 ranged from 2 to 6 inches, with the highest totals occurring north of M-46.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated 10-12 inches of snow over a 20-hour period near Stephenson.  Northeast winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused impressive drifting of the snow.  Most area schools were closed on both the 12th and the 13th due to storm impacts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening storm system moving from the Plains into Lower Michigan dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

Low pressure would advance out of the central plains, crossing the Thumb area of lower Michigan on the night of the 12th. Snow expanded north into the area early on the 12th. Heavier snow fell in the morning into mid afternoon, followed by a brief lull, before heavier snow returned again that evening. Snowfall was enhanced into northeast lower Michigan during this part of the event, thanks to east winds off of Lake Huron. And, after the system departed, moderate lake effect snow fell in some of the snowbelts of northern Michigan well into the 13th. The highest snowfall amounts included 16 inches in Rogers City, and around a foot in Petoskey and Alpena. Substantial blowing and drifting snow resulted from winds gusting up to 40 mph after the system departed.

Low pressure would advance out of the central plains, crossing the Thumb area of lower Michigan on the night of the 12th. Snow expanded north into the area early on the 12th. Heavier snow fell in the morning into mid afternoon, followed by a brief lull, before heavier snow returned again that evening. Snowfall was enhanced into northeast lower Michigan during this part of the event, thanks to east winds off of Lake Huron. And, after the system departed, moderate lake effect snow fell in some of the snowbelts of northern Michigan well into the 13th. The highest snowfall amounts included 16 inches in Rogers City, and around a foot in Petoskey and Alpena. Substantial blowing and drifting snow resulted from winds gusting up to 40 mph after the system departed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall across the county ranged from 16 inches in Marquette to nearly 26 inches in Negaunee, including the NWS Marquette office, with one to two inch per hour snowfall rates observed during the event.  Calendar day snowfall records were broken on both the 12th and 13th at the NWS Marquette office and a daily precipitation record of 1.30 inches was set on the 12th.  Area schools were closed on both the 12th and the 13th due to the heavy snow, and Northern Michigan University was closed on the 13th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening storm system moving from the Plains into Lower Michigan dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Munising measured 12 inches of snow in less than 24 hours. Schools were closed or dismissed early on the 12th in advance of the storm and remained closed on the 13th due to impacts from the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening storm system moving from the Plains into Lower Michigan dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Garden Corners measured ten inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  Most schools were closed on the 12th and delayed two hours on the 13th due to effects from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening storm system moving from the Plains into Lower Michigan dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.

Weak low pressure would slowly organize as it moved east from Iowa. Initial light snow gave way to heavy snow as the system made its closest approach on the night of the 14th. The heaviest snowfall fell in eastern upper Michigan, mainly near and east of I-75. Hulbert picked up 11 inches of snow, while St Ignace, Hessel, Kinross, and Drummond Island were all in the 8 to 10 inch range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to four inches of wet snow fell in five hours across much of the county.  This wet snow combined with the weight of snow from previous storms earlier in the month caused damage to three farm buildings in Harris Township.  One free stall barn collapsed and killed 27 cows.  Damage estimates from the loss of the buildings and livestock approached $150,000.  Many churches and businesses were closed on the 24th due to impacts from the storm. Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to around 60 mph downed tree limbs and power lines and resulted in widespread power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high wind event occurred with wind gusts reaching the 55 to 65 mph range that resulted in the loss of power to around a million people on the 24th into the 25th.  In Kent county alone over 280,000 people lost power.  Over a hundred thousand people lost power across Kalamazoo county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to near 50 mph resulted in blizzard conditions with blowing snow and near zero visibilities.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions developd on Sunday February 24th with moderate to heavy snow and blowing snow due to wind gusts of 45 to 50 mph that resulted in near zero visibilities at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county during the afternoon of the 24th and continuing into the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds, gusting to an estimated 45 mph at times, caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow as many roads were drifted shut and closed, including Highway M-28.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county during the afternoon and evening of the 24th. Northwest winds gusting to 45 to 55 mph at times  caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many secondary roads. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.

The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.

Northwest winds gusting to 50 to 60 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many roads, including Highway M-28. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county from the afternoon into the morning of the 25th. Northwest winds gusting to 50 to 60 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many roads, including Highway M-28. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed throughout the county from the afternoon of the 24th into the early morning of the 25th. Northwest winds gusting to 50 to 60 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many roads, including Highway M-28 east of Harvey.  Some higher terrain locations across the county reported nearly two feet of storm total snowfall.  The weight of heavy snow from this storm and previous storms during the month of February caused numerous roof collapses of businesses throughout the county.  The heavy snow also caused the roof of the Negaunee Bus Depot to collapse which alone caused damage in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.  Schools throughout the county, including Northern Michigan University, were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county from the afternoon of the 24th into the early morning of the 25th. Northwest winds gusting to 60 mph at times caused extreme blowing and drifting of snow and closed all roads across the northern part of the county. All schools throughout the county, including Michigan Technological University, were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.

A low pressure system quickly intensified over the weekend of February 23-24th, as it crossed the Great Lakes region.  This system brought blizzard warnings to western portions of the Great Lakes to high winds across the rest of the region.  A well-mixed boundary layer led to high winds over the region, with gusts around 60 mph range. Widespread downed tree limbs with sporadic structural damage reported. One such report was roof damage at Adrian College. Downed power lines led to close to 200,000 customers without power across southeast Michigan, with some of outages lasting into Monday. Here are some of the higher wind gusts reported:|Saginaw... 61 mph|Detroit...   61 mph|Pontiac...   56 mph|Flint...       55 mph|Ann Arbor...  55 mph|Adrian...       55 mph|Lapeer...       53 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts over 60 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage. The Hillsdale airport recorded a 66 mph wind gust.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system developed across the western Great Lakes on Sunday, February 24th. Widespread 30 to 40 mph prevailing west winds occurred with gusts of 45 to 68 mph. These high winds were of long duration (approximately 13-16 hours) and this was considered unprecedented based on local climatology. Numerous reports of downed large trees, large tree limbs, and utility poles were received along with many power outages across the entire area. The highest wind gust of the event was at KAOH with a 68 mph gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts 50 to 55 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts over 58 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage. The Benton Harbor airport recorded a 62 mph wind gust.

The highest wind gust of the event was at KAOH with a 68 mph gust.

A high-impact winter storm blasted northern Michigan with ice, snow, and wind. Intense low pressure would move almost due north up the long axis of Lake Michigan on the 24th. The initial push of precipitation into northern Michigan fell as freezing rain, with a number of places seeing around an eighth of an inch of ice accumulation on the day and night of the 23rd. Cold air blasted back into the region during the day and night of the 24th, on high westerly winds. That changed precipitation to snow, which diminished early on the 25th. The highest snowfall amounts were 11 inches near Gaylord, and 7 inches near Sault Ste Marie as well as Cadillac. Meanwhile, wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph were common during the day and night of the 24th. Mackinac Island had a measured gust to 63 mph, and Traverse City gusted to 60 mph. A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

Meanwhile, wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph were common during the day and night of the 24th. Mackinac Island had a measured gust to 63 mph, and Traverse City gusted to 60 mph. A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts of 50 to 55 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system developed across the western Great Lakes on Sunday, February 24th. Widespread 30 to 40 mph prevailing west winds occurred with gusts of 45 to 68 mph. These high winds were of long duration (approximately 13-16 hours) and this was considered unprecedented based on local climatology. Numerous reports of downed large trees, large tree limbs, and utility poles were received along with many power outages across the entire area. The highest wind gust of the event was at KAOH with a 68 mph gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts of 50 to 55 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage.

The highest wind gust of the event was at KAOH with a 68 mph gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of wet snow was reported in 12 hours across the county, greatest far south near the city of Menominee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Bergland measured 3.5 inches of snow in approximately ten hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Ironwood measured 5.4 inches of wet snow in less than 18 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured three inches of snow in approximately ten hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of wet snow was reported in the Escanaba-Gladstone area and in Stonington in just over a 12-hour period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Manistique and Cooks measured three inches of wet snow in seven hours.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from near Redridge to Calumet measured six to seven inches of snow in less than 18 hours.  Large drifts were observed in Calumet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers seven miles southwest of Wetmore and near Grand Marais measured five to six inches of snow in 21 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter southeast of Big Bay measured 3.5 inches of snow in less than 11 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of rain and snowmelt resulted in flooding and closure of more than a hundred roads.  30 roads were completely washed out.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Thursday March 14, 2019 three rounds of thunderstorms combined to drop approximately 1.5 inches of rain on much of Newaygo County. In addition, the ground was frozen and approximately 4 inches of snow water equivalent was contained in the snowpack. About 2.5 inches of this snow water melted and joined the rainfall runoff. ||These 3 factors all resulted in rapid and significant flooding across parts of the county that resulted in more than 50 homes and 9 businesses flooded, as well as the closure of more than 100 roads and the complete washout of more than 30 roads. A series of private dams on Penoyer Creek were also damaged. In addition, in the days after the storm, minor flooding developed along the Muskegon River that resulted in the flooding of an additional 105 homes. Damages from this storm across the county were more than $1.7 Million.

A warm front draped across the region provided a focus for thunderstorm development. Although MUCAPE was 500 J/KG or less across the region, 0 to 3 km helicity in excess of 500 m2/s2 and effective shear of 60 to 80 knots allowed for some organization to storms with hail and isolated wind damage being the main impacts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail of up to half dollar size (an inch and a quarter) was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported several trees were blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front draped across the region provided a focus for thunderstorm development. Although MUCAPE was 500 J/KG or less across the region, 0 to 3 km helicity in excess of 500 m2/s2 and effective shear of 60 to 80 knots allowed for some organization to storms with hail and isolated wind damage being the main impacts.

The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 67 mph peak wind gust was measured at South Haven Regional Airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.

A warm front draped across the region provided a focus for thunderstorm development. Although MUCAPE was 500 J/KG or less across the region, 0 to 3 km helicity in excess of 500 m2/s2 and effective shear of 60 to 80 knots allowed for some organization to storms with hail and isolated wind damage being the main impacts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail stones of an inch to inch and a quarter were measured in Charlotte.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down around the intersection of Britton Rd and I-69 and produced EF-0 damage up to Bancroft Rd and Newburg Rd with large tree limbs downed and trees snapped. Shoreline Lake Condos had over 10 trailers and mobile homes damaged from falling trees. The tornado continued northeast from Bancroft Rd/Newburg Rd to M-71 just ESE of Vernon producing EF-2 damage. One roof was completely taken off, a second story wall collapsed, and numerous homes with wall damage.  The tornado weakened back down to EF-1 as two more home damaged near Bennington Rd Reed Rd.  The tornado finally lifted near Riniel Rd just south of Lytle Rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down close to the intersection of Bennington Greens Drive and Innsbrook Drive, snapping pine trees. The tornado continued northeast, crossing M-52 near West Grand River Road. Hardwood trees were observed snapped with large limbs down. The tornado then hit a Farm along South Morrice Road, just south of W Garrison Road. Trees were uprooted and a well built farm outbuilding lost its roof. The tornado snapped additional trees near Vandecarr and Bennington Roads before lifting near the Maple River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down on Nichols Rd just south of Corunna Rd before traveling east/northeast to Calkins Rd just east of Morrish Rd. Damage included downed and snapped trees, large limbs, and a collapsed pole barn.  The tornado lifted near Jennings Rd just north of Pasadena Ave.
