Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of Stanley and Bray Roads and quickly tracked off to the northeast. The storm lifted near the M-57 and Irish Road intersection. The tornado was strongest when it hit the Camelot Villas off of Genesee Road. A mobile home was flipped onto its side, with another mobile home partially blown off the foundation. Roof and siding damage was prevalent within the mobile park. Clusters of trees were snapped and tree tops sheared along the tornado path, with a couple other small trailers flipped.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 7.7 inches of lake effect snow in 18 hours at Ironwood.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow accumulated over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured 5.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow accumulated over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of nearly four inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours near Hancock.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow accumulated over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 16th.

Snow pack with 2 inches of liquid water equivalent melted, coupled with rainfall slightly above half of an inch, caused the Tittabawassee River at Midland  to reach moderate flood level. The river peaked at 25.41 feet during the morning of March 16th.  Several roads were closed due to flooding, including parts of US-10.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant and wet snow pack along with moderate rainfall at times contributed to minor flooding along the Sturgeon River from the 8th into early on the 13th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Anomalously wet late season snow pack along with a period of moderate rainfall caused minor flooding on the Sturgeon River from the 8th until early on the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between four and eight inches of wet snow fell over much of Menominee County during the event.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times. East winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.  Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

Easterly winds of 30 to 40 MPH on April 11th lead to high water levels over the Western Lake Erie basin and large wave action, causing lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked just above 90 inches above Low Water Daturm, while Fermi and Gibralter both peaked out around 78 inches during the afternoon hours. Residents were evacuated in Frenchtown Charter Township and Luna Pier, as homes were impacted with some homes under water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Marenisco measured nearly six inches of wet snow in less than ten hours.  Sleet also mixed in with the snow at times.  A few schools had delayed start times on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of wet snow and sleet accumulated from three to six inches over much of Iron County on the 11th.  West Iron County Schools were closed on the 12th to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across the county measured between four and seven inches of snow over a 14-hour period.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured at the Muskegon airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season brought high winds with several locations reporting peak wind gusts of 45 to near 60 mph.  A peak wind gust to 59 mph was reported at the Muskegon airport. There were also several reports of one to three inches of snow north of I-96.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across Ontonagon County measured between four and six inches of wet snow over an approximate 12-hour period.  Sleet likely mixed in with the snow at times.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

Easterly winds of 30 to 40 MPH on April 11th lead to high water levels over the Western Lake Erie basin and large wave action, causing lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked just above 90 inches above Low Water Daturm, while Fermi and Gibralter both peaked out around 78 inches during the afternoon hours. Residents were evacuated in Frenchtown Charter Township and Luna Pier, as homes were impacted with some homes under water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of two to three inches of wet heavy snow in less than five hours in Escanaba.  Scattered power outages were reported due to the heavy snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated four to six inches of wet snow in less than ten hours across the county.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.  Area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters measured between four and seven inches of wet snow in approximately 10 hours.  Area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports throughout the county measured anywhere from three to six inches of wet snow over an approximate 10-hour time period.  Marquette Board of Light and Power reported scattered power outages from the wet snow, and area schools were closed throughout the county on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported between four to six inches of heavy wet snow during the late afternoon and evening hours across northern Houghton County.  Snowfall rates of an inch per hour or greater combined with east winds gusting to 45 mph caused near whiteout conditions and power outages from late afternoon into the early morning of the 12th.  Schools through the county were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated four to six inches of wet snow over approximately 9 hours. Sleet likely mixed in with the snow at times.  East winds gusting to 40 mph also caused near whiteout conditions at times in snow and blowing snow and power outages during the evening of the 11th.  Many area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated between one to two tenths of an inch of ice in Newberry from late evening on the 11th through the early morning of the 12th.  The freezing rain and east winds gusting over 30 mph at times caused scattered power outages over the county. The freezing rain also mixed with snow and sleet at times on the morning of the 12th. Tahquamenon Area Schools were delayed two hours on the 12th due to the impacts from the mixed precipitation and gusty winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over six inches of snow was reported near Shelby and Stony Lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eight inches of snow was reported near Cloverville and Norton Shores.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was reported in Hersey.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was reported in Weidman.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine inches of snow was reported by CoCoRaHs observers near Big Rapids and Sylvester.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported six inches of snow near White Cloud.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.

Low pressure would strengthen as it moved northeast across the eastern Great Lakes on the night of the 14th. Other than a touch of rain at onset, precipitation was almost exclusively snow in northern lower Michigan. Snowfall totals of six to nine inches were common, along and southeast of a line from Cadillac to Alpena. However, the only concentrated area that reported over eight inches of snow was in Roscommon County. Eight to nine inches of snow fell on Roscommon, Houghton and Higgins Lake, St Helen, and the Twin Lakes area.

Renewed easterly winds of 30 to 35 mph on April 14th sent water levels over Western Lake Erie up once again, with peak water levels coming up a few inches from the April 11th values. None-the-less, renewed lakeshore flooding was reported in many of the same areas.

Renewed easterly winds of 30 to 35 mph on April 14th sent water levels over Western Lake Erie up once again, with peak water levels coming up a few inches from the April 11th values. None-the-less, renewed lakeshore flooding was reported in many of the same areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor flooding along the Sturgeon River from the 18th through the end of the month.  ||The Houghton County emergency manager reported that several houses and barns near the Sturgeon River at Chassell had rising water around them but no structures were inundated.  Sturgeon River Road was reported to be under 6-8 inches of water and Rajala Road was under 8-10 inches of water.  Multiple sections of Halonen Road near Pelkie and adjacent fields were reported to be under water the morning of 04/23 as the Sturgeon River crested.  Rain and snow melt runoff along with some clogged culverts led to Highway M-26 being closed south of Hubbell on the night of the 22nd due to water over the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gages Creek overflowed its banks onto private property east of Peavy Pond on April 19th.  Minor flooding was also reported on the Paint and Michigamme Rivers from the 23rd into the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the 20th, the Big Cedar River near Powers was inundating yards up near a few porches.  Other minor roads in Menominee County were reportedly under some water during this time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Willow Creek in Escanaba spilled over onto Willow Creek Road on the 20th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Norrie Park Road in Ironwood between Lime Street and Riverside Road was closed on the 22nd due to the failure of a small, old dam on the Montreal River.  Water was also reported over Black River Road near McDonald Dam on April 22.  On April 24th, numerous road closures were reported in the City of Wakefield as the Little Black River and Sunday Lake rose outside their banks. The city enlisted students to fill and place sandbags around the city.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred into Dickinson County along the Michigamme River from the 23rd through the end of the month.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant wet snow pack combined with moderate to heavy rain at times caused minor flooding along the Michigamme River near Republic and Witch Lake and along the Middle Branch of the Escanaba near Humboldt from 23rd through the end of the month.  Some minor flooding was also reported along the Chocolay River near Harvey from the 18th through the 19th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.

Heavy rain with thunderstorms produced 2 to 4 inches of rain in about a 4 hour window across the I-94 corridor. This amount of rain in a short period caused flash flooding across parts of Wayne County, with the Dearborn Heights area being hardest hit. About 5000 homes experienced basement flooding, with 1000 homes or so suffering major flood damage.  Several road closures occurred or were rendered impassable as  many cars were stalled out in the high water over the roadways.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches wet snow fell in less than eight hours over higher terrain from Painesdale north to Calumet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Central Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and produced moderate snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The excessive rainfall also caused flooding across Ecorse Creek and Rouge River. Ecorse Creek in Dearborn Heights peaked at 9.77 feet during the early morning hours of May 1st. The Lower Rouge River at Dearborn peaked just above 10.5 feet around noon on May 1st.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain with thunderstorms produced 2 to 4 inches of rain in about a 4 hour window across the I-94 corridor. This amount of rain in a short period caused flash flooding across parts of Wayne County, with the Dearborn Heights area being hardest hit. About 5000 homes experienced basement flooding, with 1000 homes or so suffering major flood damage.  Several road closures occurred or were rendered impassable as  many cars were stalled out in the high water over the roadways.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate snow accumulation ranging from four to six inches occurred over a 12-hour period from Michigamme east to Negaunee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Central Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and produced moderate snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 1st.

Persistent strong north to east winds and extremely high river levels along the St. Clair River caused numerous roads and buildings to be flooded in Algonac and Harsens Island. The water level at Algonac peaked at 60 inches above LWD on May 9th around 230 PM LST.

Record high water levels over Lake Erie, coupled with easterly winds of 20 to 30 MPH lead to lakeshore flooding across eastern Monroe, and eastern Wayne County. The water level at Toledo peak at 86 inches at 1536 LST on May 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltar peaking at 78 inches and 76 inches respectively about an hour later. The Village of Estral Beach observed homeowners stranded in their homes due to the flood waters, with Firefighters assisting in evacuations. While Estral Beach residents were hit hardest by the flood waters from Lake Erie, several county beachfront communities also were inundated by water, particularly in Grand Beach in Frenchtown Township, North Shores in LaSalle, Avalon Beach in Monroe Township and Allen Cove in Luna Pier.

While Estral Beach residents were hit hardest by the flood waters from Lake Erie, several county beachfront communities also were inundated by water, particularly in Grand Beach in Frenchtown Township, North Shores in LaSalle, Avalon Beach in Monroe Township and Allen Cove in Luna Pier.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lake St. Clair water level at St. Clair Shores peaked at 61 inches, which caused flooding in Harris Township, which included Jefferson Road being flooded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record high water levels over Lake Erie, coupled with easterly winds of 20 to 30 MPH lead to lakeshore flooding across eastern Monroe, and eastern Wayne County. The water level at Toledo peak at 86 inches at 1536 LST on May 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltar peaking at 78 inches and 76 inches respectively about an hour later. The Village of Estral Beach observed homeowners stranded in their homes due to the flood waters, with Firefighters assisting in evacuations. While Estral Beach residents were hit hardest by the flood waters from Lake Erie, several county beachfront communities also were inundated by water, particularly in Grand Beach in Frenchtown Township, North Shores in LaSalle, Avalon Beach in Monroe Township and Allen Cove in Luna Pier.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water entered some of the historic fishing shanties in the Fishtown section of Leland. Sandbags and other methods were deployed to attempt to keep the water out.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The sudden relaxation of a gusty east wind, and quick transition to a northwest wind, resulted in a seiche on Lake Michigan. With very high water levels already in place on all of the Great Lakes, localized flooding developed.

Record water levels on Lake Erie, coupled with easterly winds around 20 mph caused lakeshore flooding again across parts of Eastern Monroe County. The water level at Toledo peaked at 77 inches around 730 LST on the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Windmill peaked at 61 inches above LWD around 500 AM LST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record water levels on Lake Erie, coupled with easterly winds around 20 mph caused lakeshore flooding again across parts of Eastern Monroe County. The water level at Toledo peaked at 77 inches around 730 LST on the 12th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and power lines were reported down, with one tree falling onto a house.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed over Genesee and Tusocola Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large tree limbs were reported down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed over Genesee and Tusocola Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed over Genesee and Tusocola Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 56 knot peak wind gust was measured at the South Haven GLERL site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that a large tree was blown down near the intersection of 84th street and Alden Nash road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A power pole was uprooted and tree limbs were blown down west of Clarksville.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power poles and trees were blown down.

In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that several trees were blown down near the intersection of Wyman and Deaner roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey found that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county.  The tornado damage path began on Barryville Road about one |quarter mile south of Cloverdale Road and ended on Marshall Road about a quarter mile south of Maple Grove Road. Three barns on one farm were damaged just southeast of the intersection of Barryville and Cloverdale Road and a telephone pole was blown down a few hundred feet northeast of the barns. About a dozen trees were|snapped or uprooted along the path of the tornado.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was reported at the Sturgeon River near Alston during the afternoon the early evening of the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported trees and power lines down across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCS tracked east-northeast from east-central MO/central IL Wednesday evening (May 22) through the IWX CWA early Thursday morning (May 23). Widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph, with embedded channeled microburst gusts in excess of 70 mph, occurred with associated bowing segments.

Thunderstorms developed north of an incoming warm front on the night of the 24th. The strongest storms produced hail.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain, with 1 to 4 inches reported, generally along and north of I-69. Locations across southeast Saginaw and southwest Tuscola counties saw the heaviest rain, just over 4 inches which caused significant flooding, resulting in at least 4.5 million dollars of damage. Numerous roads around Frankenmuth were flooded, but most of the road washouts and damage occurred across the county line in southwest Tuscola county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds gusting in excess of 40 mph uprooted a tree unto an RV trailer in Van Riper State Park campground on the afternoon of the 25th.  The tree was healthy so the observer suspected that the saturated ground contributed to it being uprooted.  The RV trailer was crushed by the tree, but no injuries were reported.  Many other branches came down at the campground.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds gusting in excess of 40 mph uprooted a tree unto an RV trailer in Van Riper State Park campground on the afternoon of the 25th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to around one and three quarters of an inch in diameter was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of large hail as well as a little bit of wind damage in association with severe thunderstorms on June 1st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs reported down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wedge of instability built in across southern Michigan throughout the late morning and afternoon and was the source of numerous strong thunderstorms, many of which produced both severe wind gusts to 60 mph and hail up to 1.25 inches for locations along the I-69 corridor and south down to the Ohio border. Most of the severe hail was confined to Lenawee and Monroe Counties, but pea (1/4) to penny (3/4) sized hail was observed at multiple locations across southeast Michigan. Additionally, a line of thunderstorms extending north from Milan and Ann Arbor up to Flint pushed east throughout the afternoon and produced sporadic 60 mph wind gusts, resulting in scattered tree damage, isolated building damage, and power outages.

Easterly winds of 15 to 30 mph over western Lake Erie lead to some lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked at 76.1 inches above LWD during the evening of June 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltor peaking around 72 inches above LWD.

Easterly winds of 15 to 30 mph over western Lake Erie lead to some lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked at 76.1 inches above LWD during the evening of June 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltor peaking around 72 inches above LWD.

Thunderstorms caused easterly winds to reach 30 mph or greater, which caused a rapid rise in water levels over western Lake Erie and the Detroit River. Gibraltar's water level peaked at 81.1 inches above chart datum just before midnight, with Fermi and Toledo's water levels holding around 76 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire officials reported multiple trees and power lines down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow boundaries from convection across central Lower Michigan and subtle shortwaves passing through the region caused thunderstorms to develop. High CAPE values but low shear allowed the storms to form quickly but struggle to organize. Eventually, greater DCAPE values arrive with one of the waves and caused more extensive wind damage in a few locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to severe numerous thunderstorms developed in the late afternoon hours, mainly along and south of the M-59 corridor. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local dispatch officials reported trees across the road. Also, power lines were reported down on Mason Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow boundaries from convection across central Lower Michigan and subtle shortwaves passing through the region caused thunderstorms to develop. High CAPE values but low shear allowed the storms to form quickly but struggle to organize. Eventually, greater DCAPE values arrive with one of the waves and caused more extensive wind damage in a few locations.

Prolonged easterly winds of 10 to 20 mph lead to lakeshore flooding along the Western Lake Erie shoreline and Lake St. Clair shoreline. The water level at Toledo peaked at 81 inches above LWD around noon on July 7th, while Fermi and  Gibraltar both peaked close to 78 inches. Meanwhile, across Lake St. Clair, St. Clair shores peaked around 67 inches above LWD in the late evening hours of July 7th, while Windmill Point reached their peak during the late evening hours of July 6th just above 67 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A well-organized squall line would weaken as it crossed northern Lake Michigan and northwest lower Michigan. However, a few locations saw damaging wind gusts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down in Sheridan and Branch townships.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe storms resulted in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines. Peak wind gusts were estimated at up to around 70 to 80 mph.  In addition 6 to 10 inches of rain fell across much of Mason and Lake counties.  There were several road washouts, a few culvert failures, and a couple of bridge washouts.  At least 48 homes were damaged by water in Lake county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved repeatedly over Manistee County in the morning and afternoon of the 20th. Excessive rainfall produced substantial flooding across central and southern Manistee County. By late on the 20th, rainfall totals reached 8.90 in Parkdale (near Manistee), and 5.95 in Wellston. Water entered numerous homes and stores in the greater Manistee area, and in Dublin, resulting in property damage. The campground at Orchard Beach State Park was at one point under four feet of water. Many roads were flooded and closed to travel for several hours. 12th Street in the city of Manistee was washed out. Places near the Manistee River were most susceptible to flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of regenerating thunderstorms produced excessive rainfall and some severe weather in northern lower Michigan.
